texts.en: Mrs. Hun S. O., together with her husband, to support the family works as a farmer. She makes on average around $4 a day of profit. They have three children and all of them are students. To improve their living condition, this couple hopes to get a loan from Kiva. This money will be used to purchase a plot of land to farm in dry season in order to gain more yield.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to farm in order to gain more yield

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Din

texts.en: Mrs. Din S., 28, works as a housewife: she stays at home cooking food and looking after the children for her entire family. To supplement the household income her husband works as a taxi driver in Phnom Penh, typically earning about $10 a day. To have additional income, he decided to get a loan from Kiva to open another small business for his wife. The loan will be used to purchase a large amount of bananas in his village to resell to the market for profit.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of bananas to resell to the market for profit

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Salelologa I Centre - Group 1

texts.en: While Salelologa, the capital village of Savaii Island, is largely semi-urbanized, its outlying areas are still agricultural.  The Salelologa I Centre is located in a largely agricultural area and the people in the community still subsist on farming and vegetable gardening. It is also their main source of income.  The women who formed the Salelologa I Centre are determined to improve their present living conditions.  With the help of small loans from SPBD they will be able to upgrade their farms and vegetable gardens and also expand into other income-generating activities including: sewing, elei printing, and pancake-making.  These activities are a good way of augmenting their household income.

loans.use: to purchase farming implements, agricultural supplies and pay for additional farm labor

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Mrs. Tep S., 25, is a mother of three children. She stays at home, cooks food and looks after the children. Her husband, Mr. Socheat, 29, is a blacksmith, who earns approximately $6 a day of profit. Now this couple aims to get a loan from Kiva to purchase a power plant to assist in blacksmithing. (Mrs. Tep S. took this picture with her mom.)

loans.use: To purchase a power plant

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Rabiyya

texts.en: Rabiyya A. is 51, married with four children, and lives in the village of Saatli city in the south-central area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Rabiyya owns a small herd of cows and sells milk in the Saatli bazaar. Her family expenditures are increasing as the children grow. Rabiyya plans to increase the number of cows she has in order to increase her income. For this purpose, Rabiyya applied to the Normicro Saatli branch for a loan of $600. She hopes this loan will help her improve her family's life.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow for her dairy business

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin T. is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 20 years old and lives in the Saatli town in the south-central area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Elchin rents a small shop in the local bazaar of Saatli town and sells food. The business is very successful but he needs capital to increase the inventory of his shop. Elchin has no collateral to apply to the commercial banks. That's why he applied to the Normicro Saatli branch for a loan of $500. This credit would allow him to buy and sell more goods and to provide himself with the necessities of life.

loans.use: To increase the volume of his grocery business

loans.name: Yea

texts.en: Mrs. Yea S., 38, together with her husband, works as a farmer and every day earns around $4 of profit. They have two children and both of them are students. This couple plans to purchase a rice mill. This machine is not only for personal use but they can take advantage of it; for example, they can rent it to the villagers to have more profits.

loans.use: To purchase a rice mill

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Chon

texts.en: Mrs. Chon L., 66, is married with two children and works as a housewife. She stays at home, looks after the children, and cooks food for the family members. Her husband works as a construction laborer and produces on average about $7.50 a day. As doing construction work is not good for older people, they now want to change careers with a loan from Kiva. They will take this money to purchase a car to run as a taxi. They do believe that to be a driver is more comfortable than a worker and sometimes it can produce more profits to sustain the family.

loans.use: To purchase a car to run as a taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Somoye's Ushirika Group

texts.en:
Somoye is 36 years old and is married woman with two 16-year-old children. She and her husband also take care of two other people, aged 60 and 65 years old. Somoye owns a small food vendor store that she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Somoye now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food selling.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Mrs. Chim Y., 35, is a mother of two children and, together with her husband, works as a construction laborer. Every day they can earn about $5. The cost of their commute is high so now they are requesting a loan from Kiva to own a motorbike. Before they rode to their work place by motor-taxi so it cost them a lot. (Mrs. Chim Y. took a picture with a motorbike that she is going to buy).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for their commute

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bano's Group

texts.en:
I am Bano Z. N., a mother of eight children who lives with my family in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. Two of my daughters are married and the others attend school. To make a living, I sell cloth from my house to the women in my neighborhood. I need a loan to expand my inventory and improve my income.

My group members in need of loans are: Mehnaz B., who will buy cardboard with her share of loan, Bhoola B., who wants to buy a sewing machine; Razia B. will use her share of the loan to repair their rickshaw; Samia B. needs this loan to buy paints and brushes for her family’s paint business.

These women reside in my neighborhood and I completely trust them. Please help us by lending immediately as we do not want to miss good business opportunities.

loans.use: Buy cloth in bulk

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok K., 30, works as a fish vendor in the market and normally earns around $2.50 a day of profit. Her husband, to support the family, works raising fish and he makes around $2.50 a day, too. This couple hopes to use the loan to purchase a motorbike to transfer the fish to the market, and some of the money will be spent on fish food and to buy more small fish to breed in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike, fish food and small fish to breed in the future

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sada's Ushirika Group

texts.en:
Sada is 39 years old and is married with two children, ages 13 and 12 years old. She and her husband also take care of five other people. Sada has sold food since 2000. Every day, she works from 7am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Aisha, who has a business dealing in Salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Munnawer's Group

texts.en:
My name is Munnawer B. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of seven children, of which three are married. I work in a public institute and one of my sons is a rickshaw driver. He needs a loan to fix his rickshaw and purchase new tires for it.

My other group members would use the loan as follows: Shahnaz A. wants to purchase wood; Maqboola B. sells cloth and would like to purchase additional inventory. I volunteered to become their leader so that I could help them get loans for their businesses.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw and purchase tires

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Mrs. Tim N., 28, owns a plot of farmland together with her husband. They work growing a variety of vegetables, making on average around $2.50 a day. Beside growing vegetables they still breed pigs for resale. So now they are currently requesting a loan to purchase food to reserve for pigs.

loans.use: To purchase food for pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Veronica's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Veronica is 30 years old and has a two-year-old child. Veronica owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 9:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

Veronica now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Edita, who has a business selling clothes (a "batique").

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
I am Rehana B., the group leader and mother of four boys, three of whom attend a local school. The youngest is not yet of school age. I want my children to complete their studies and find decent employment for themselves. My husband manufactures shoes and sells them in a nearby market. I also help him in his business. We would use the loan to increase our inventory of shoes for resale.

Shama R. manufactures cardboard boxes. Shamim A. sews clothes and wants to buy a new sewing machine. Mumtaz A. intends to use this loan to fix her husband’s car. Parween B. will purchase additional plants for her husband’s nursery. This is a group loan and we are mutually responsible for its repayment.

loans.use: Expand shoe manufacturing business and purchase required raw materials in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hout

texts.en: Mrs. Hout S., 42, is a rice vendor, who makes on average about $4 a day of income. Her husband Mr. Saom Sophea, 47, is a police officer, whose salary is $60 a month. To push the rice selling now they are requesting a loan to purchase more rice to sell. They do hope that the increase of rice selling would produce more profits. Moreover, some part of the loan they will spend on house construction.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kireka B5 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Zulaika N.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Zulaika is 34 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 7 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Zulaika makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a shop selling air time cards. Zulaika has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Zulaika is joined in her small group by Florence T., Maria N., Annet N., and Fatuma L.. Florence T. has a business running a restaurant and wants to rent bigger business premises. Maria N. is currently operating a business selling cabbages and wants a loan to boost business. Annet N. operates a business selling spare parts and wants to invest more in the business. Fatuma L. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to start up a salon business.

loans.use: To add to salon business

loans.name: Joyce's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Joyce is 38 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 5 and 2 years old. Joyce owns a small shop that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 5am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $290 from her sales.

Joyce now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Helena and Mwaya, who have businesses dealing in pharmaceuticals and food vending.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Zohra's Group

texts.en:
I am Zohra B. from Lahore, Pakistan. I have five boys and two girls. My husband is a rickshaw driver and earns minimum income. I am requesting a second loan for my son to purchase additional inventory for his shoe business and thus improve the family's income.

The other women in my group would use the loan in the following ways: Farzana B. wants to purchase a rickshaw; Fozia B. will buy cloth; Nomi B. will use her loan to repair her family’s rickshaw (a local three-wheeled taxi); Rukhsana B. will also use the loan to repair her husband’s rickshaw. All of these women are friends and dream of a successful life.

loans.use: Expand shoe business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tun

texts.en: Mrs. Tun S., 35, is a mother of three children and has opened a small business (cleaning motors and cars). Normally she earns $4 a day of profit. Her husband, to supplement the household income, works at the Ministry of Environment. His salary is $40 a month. Then after his work he always takes time to help at his wife’s business. So now this couple needs some money to purchase some tools for cleaning motors and cars, which cost around $100.

loans.use: To purchase cleaning tools

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kireka B5 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Prossy B.. She is currently in the business of operating a cosmetic's shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics. Prossy is 31 years old and is married. Her husband is a plumber. She has 2 children aged 3 and 6, and her children go to school. Each week, Prossy makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's school fees. Prossy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Prossy is joined in her small group by Catherine B., Specioza Namanda, Rashida N., and Sarah W.. Catherine B. has a business running a retail shop and wants to to expand to wholesale selling. Specioza Namadna is currently operating a canteen business and wants a loan to expand to a retail shop. Rashida N. operates a business of selling cold drinks and wants to purchase another fridge. Sarah W. is currently in the business of selling snacks and is requesting a loan to change to a durable business.

loans.use: To boost cosmetic sales business

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
My name is Khursheed B. and I am the group leader for this loan. I am requesting money for one of my sons who sells cloth. He purchases his cloth in Peshawar--a city famous for its inexpensive, quality products.

The other women in my group are requesting loans for the following uses; Zahida B. needs a loan to repair her rickshaw; Hameeda B.’s husband runs a light decoration business and would like to increase his inventory; Bushra S. intends to purchase more rice for resale; Basheera B. needs to increase the number of items for her grocery store. These women are my friends and we always help each other in time of need.

loans.use: Purchase cloth for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Gulzar's Group

texts.en:
My name is Gulzar B.. I am a widow and the group leader from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. My sons manufacture cardboard boxes. They need a loan to buy a few items for their business. They are the breadwinners and work very hard to earn income for the family.

Another in my loan group, Asma B., needs a loan to buy a movie camera for her husband so he can be hired to shoot movies at various occasions. The third woman in the group, Guddo B., will use her share of the loan to purchase raw materials required to make shoes. This is a group loan and we are mutually responsible for its' repayment.

loans.use: Purchase cardboard and raw materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Madina's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Madina is 36 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 8, 4, and 2 years. Madina manufactures and sells clothing in her "batique" business, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6.30am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Madina now hopes for a loan to buy more materials for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Rehema, Zena and Marium, who have businesses dealing in tailoring and food vending.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more materials  for a clothing business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im S., 39 years old, is a grocer who sells from her house in the Trapeng Beng Village in Kompong Cham Province, earning about $5 a day. Her husband, Mr. Kim Sokha, is a silversmith who also earns about $5 a day. She has three children, one of whom is a student, and the other two of pre-school age.
 
In order to increase her inventory of groceries, she requests a loan of $400. This loan will also further her children’s studies. She has proven to be a reliable client and promises to be punctual in her loan repayment.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of groceries for sale.

loans.name: Kireka B3 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Desi M.. She is currently in the business of poultry keeping and is requesting a loan to purchase more poultry feed. Desi is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 5 children ranging from age 6 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Desi makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to to buy a water tank. Desi has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Desi is joined in her small group by Deborah N., Nusiat N., Hadijah N., and Christine N.. Deborah N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to expand to wholesale. Nusiat N. is currently operating a grocery store business and wants a loan to buy a fridge for cooling fruits. Hadijah N. operates a retail shop business and wants to increase stock. Christine N. is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to open up a retail shop.

loans.use: To add to a poultry farming business

loans.name: Salelologa P Centre - Group 2

texts.en: Kalala has a small roadside vegetable and fruit stall where she sells the produce from her garden.  When she learned about SPBD, she started thinking about expanding her business so that she can earn more income.  She was able to convince other ladies in her village to do the same and form a support group.  While each woman has her own fruit and vegetable stall, they support each other, particularly during hard times.  The group attended the 4 session training conducted by SPBD to prepare them to be good borrowers and savers.  It is with great excitement that they are anticipating their first loan.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables seeds, gardening implements, iron roofing and timber for a roadside vegetable stall

loans.name: Rahabu's Tupendane. Group

texts.en:
Rahabu is a 38 year old married woman with three children, aged 16, 8 and 5 years. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, aged 62 years. Rahabu owns a small food store that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 5:45am to 9:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

Rahabu now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Neema and Emy, who have business dealings in food vending and sales.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for the member who fails to pay.

loans.use: To buy more food items for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kireka B3 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah N.. She is currently in the business of mushroom growing and is requesting a loan to hire more land for cultivation. Sarah is 39 years old and is single. She has 3 children ranging from age 10 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start another business. Sarah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to buy water tanks and the loan was paid back on time.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Madinah K., Sylvia N., Hanifah J., and Aidah M.. Madinah K. has a business running a retail shop and wants to rent bigger premises. Sylvia N. is currently operating a beauty salon business and wants a loan to purchase a hair steamer and more mirrors. Hanifah J. operates a retail shop business and wants to expand into wholesale selling. Aidah M. is currently in the business of selling breakables (such as pottery/ceramics) and is requesting a loan to add more stock.

loans.use: To add capital to mushroom growing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Asha's Tupendane. Group

texts.en:
Asha is 33 years old and is married with 2 children, aged 7 and 3 years . Asha started her small food store in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, May, who sells items in a shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Twekembe Development Group

texts.en:
Sarah M., 36 and the chairperson of Twekembe Development Group is in a childless marriage with 5 nieces to cater for; the eldest being 13. She has been operating a small retail shop for 6 years in Kikooza as well as selling fresh milk out of the same shop for 1 year.

Sarah is our client of 6 years and with her profits and savings, she has managed to buy a plot of land together with her husband and they are planning to build a house on the same plot. Her husband has 5 children with another wife but this does not stop Sarah from working hand-in-hand with him. She plans to open up a dairy shop in Nasuuti so that her income should increase tremendously.

loans.use: to buy sugar and salt for re-sale, as well as opening up a diary shop

loans.name: Kimnye A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rehema N.. She is currently in the business of selling firewood and is requesting a loan to purchase in bulk. Rehema is 37 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 3 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Rehema makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's education. Rehema has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rehema is joined in her small group by Mary N., Resty L., Sarah K., and Prossy N.. Mary N. has a business selling arts and crafts and wants to increase her capital stock. Resty L. is currently operating a piggery business and wants a loan to construct a piggery house. Sarah K. operates a business of clothing sales and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Prossy N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy a weighing scale and shelves.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Salelavalu Uta Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
Most of the farms in Salelavalu Uta are planted with taro, bananas, vegetables and fruits. The men do most of the labor on the farm but during harvest time they are joined by the women to harvest the crops and sell them in the neighboring Salelologa market. When the other women in the village learned that a certain group of women already were a part of SPBD's program, they asked for more information and got excited to join.

Faamelea's group is convinced that they have to constantly save some of their earnings on a weekly basis. This is so they will be able to afford things in the future without resorting to borrowing. They are so glad that SPBD not only provides loans but also accepts savings deposits , even as little as one tala (about USD 0.40). As shown in the picture, they are proudly displaying the savings accounts passbooks they have recently acquired with SPBD. The small business loans help them improve their farms and will eventually provide them with higher earnings and of course, higher savings deposits for these hardworking ladies.

loans.use: To purchase farm equipment, agricultural supplies (fertilizers, pesticides, weed killers) and pay for additional farm labor

loans.name: Banda B3B A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Annet N.. She is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to open a vegetable stall in another location. Annet is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 to 7 and her children go to school. Each week, Annet makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece pf land. Annet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 700000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Annet is joined in her small group by Zaituni N., Sulaniah B., Betty W., and Mary M.. Zaituni N. has a business in stone quarrying and wants to start up a retail shop. Sulaniah B. is currently operating a business in stone quarrying and wants a loan to add to her business. Betty W. operates a business of selling matooke and wants to start a charcoal selling business. Mary M. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge and start selling juice.

loans.use: To expand vegetable business

loans.name: Banda B3B B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joyce N.. She is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to change her business to opening up a restaurant. Joyce is 30 years old and is married with a husband that sells clothes for work. She has 3 children ranging from age 8 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a new business. Joyce has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to re-invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Madina N., Grace B., Scovia N., and Rose KoB.. Madina N. has a business in stone quarrying and wants to hire more workers. Grace B. is currently operating a business in stone quarrying and wants a loan to expand her business. Scovia N. operates a business of stone quarrying and wants to boost business. Rose KoB. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to start up a retail shop business.

loans.use: To diversify from stone quarrying to a restaurant

loans.name: Banda B3B C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hamidah W.. She is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Hamidah is 35 years old and is a widow. She has 6 children ranging from age 7 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Hamidah makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's education. Hamidah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Hamidah is joined in her small group by Harriet N., Sylvia N., Yasin B., and Iddi Z.. Harriet N. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to stock more charcoal. Sylvia N. is currently operating a stone quarrying business and wants a loan to purchase more quarrying equipment. Yasin B. operates a stone quarrying business and wants to add more capital. Iddi Z. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to increase inventory.

loans.use: To add more working capital to fish business

loans.name: Kireka A6 (I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sofia M.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to construct bigger business premises. Sofia is 48 years old and is married. She has 7 children ranging from age 18 to 30 and four of them go to school while the other three work. Each week, Sofia makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up another restaurant. Sofia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sofia is joined in her small group by Zamu N., Rehema N., Joweria N., and Eflansi N.. Zamu N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase more utensils. Rehema N. is currently operating a business selling tomatoes and wants a loan to start up a restaurant business. Joweria N. operates a business selling hardware and wants to start a poultry farming business. Eflansi N. is currently in the business of baking cakes and is requesting a loan to purchase a baking machine.

loans.use: To add to restaurant business and boost it

loans.name: Kireka A6 (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty N.. She is currently in the business of selling snacks and is requesting a loan to change to a more durable business. Betty is 35 years old and is divorced. She has 2 children aged 14 and 16, and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Aminah N., Dinah N., Barbara N., and Miriam N.. Aminah N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase food warmers. Dinah N. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to increase stock. Barbara N. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase more furniture. Miriam N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To start up another business

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 30 years old. He is married and has two children. One of them is crippled from his birth. The entrepreneur is living in his parents' house with his elderly mother and father. He has a small shop of perfumes, and he applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new and different kinds of perfumes. He wants to make new shelves and improve the shop by painting it in order to expand his project and increase his income. He wants to save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new and different kinds of perfumes.

loans.name: Kireka C1A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mastula N.. She is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to to start up a poultry business. Mastula is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a commercial motorcyclist for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Mastula makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business. Mastula has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1000000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mastula is joined in her small group by Getrude K., Getu N., Gladys M., and Mary N.. Getrude K. has a business running a restaurant and wants to open up a restaurant in another location. Getu N. is currently operating a business selling tomatoes and wants a loan to change to a durable business. Gladys M. operates a business selling ripe bananas and wants to expand to wholesale selling. Mary N. is currently in the business of selling firewood and is requesting a loan to add capital stock.

loans.use: To venture into poultry keeping business

loans.name: Kireka C1B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Justine N.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. Justine is 27 years old and is married. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 2 months to 9 years old and her children go to school. Each week, Justine makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Justine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Justine is joined in her small group by Prossy N., Hanifah N., Goretti M., and Jaliya N.. Prossy N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to develop into a supermarket. Hanifah N. is currently operating a beauty salon business and wants a loan to purchase two hair dryers and shower basins. Goretti M. operates a retail shop business and wants to open up a second shop in another location. Jaliya N. is currently in the business of selling snacks and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business buy purchasing in bulk

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 36 years old. He lives and works in Bekaa, Lebanon. Mohamad owns and operates a grocery store. This is the third time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, Mohamad would like to buy merchandise to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sustain and develop his business

loans.name: Sdao Kanleng Ii Group

texts.en:
This loA. is to a group loA. that consists of sixteen members of the Sdao Kanleng II Village Bank, located in Kandal province in Cambodia. This group loA. will be monitored by the Village Bank President, Mrs. S. Hun.

Mrs. Hun is a grocer in a local village and also a farmer. Her husband, Chhin Roth, is a construction worker and he cA. earn around $3 each dA.. Mrs. S. Hun is married with six children, three of whom are working in a garment factory. Two work as construction foremen, and the other one is enrolled in a local school. Mrs. SoA. Hun cA. generate about $2.50 in income per dA.. Thus, she would now like to request this loA. to buy more fertilizer in order to help her farm produce a better crop.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer

loans.name: Wafaa

texts.en: Wafaa is 51 years old. She lives and works in Bekaa, Lebanon. Wafaa is married and has 5 children. She owns a restaurant. This is the third time she has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, Wafaa would like to buy provisions to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional provisions and food in order to sustain and develop her business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 27 years old. He lives and works in Bekaa, Lebanon. Ali owns a pharmacy. This is the first time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, Ali would like to buy merchandise to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sustain and develop his business

loans.name: Nazih

texts.en: Nazih is a 40-year-old father of 6 children. He lives and works in Bekaa, Lebanon. Nazih sells home products. This is the first time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, Nazih would like to buy merchandise to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sustain and develop his business

loans.name: Kireka C1D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sophie K.. She is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to purchase more quarrying equipment. Sophie is 35 years old and is a widow. She has 3 children ranging from age 5 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Sophie makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's education. Sophie has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sophie is joined in her small group by Slimah D., Esther N., Sarah N., and Florence N.. Slimah D. has a business running a retail shop and wants to expand to wholesale. Esther N. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to stock more commodities. Sarah N. operates a tailoring business and wants to purchase more fabric. Florence N. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to buy more hair dryers.

loans.use: To add capital to quarrying business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kireka C1F Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Annet N.. She is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to increase the quantity of stones. Annet is 26 years old and is married. Her husband is a businessman. She has 2 children, aged 9 and 10, and her children go to school. Each week, Annet makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's education.

Annet is joined in her small group by Rose N., Kadijah N., Susan Nalwada, and Hawa T.. Rose N. has a business in stone quarrying and wants to buy more quarrying equipment. Kadijah N. is currently operating a business selling cassava and wants a loan to add more raw food. Susan Nalwada operates a business of shoe sales and wants to start a clothing sales business. Hawa T. is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling.

loans.use: To boost quarrying business and make more profits

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Group leader Mariam B. resides with her family in Lahore, Pakistan. She and her husband have three children; one girl and two boys. Mrs. B. is not educated but wants all of her children to complete their education at the local school. She works in a local school as a sweeper and her husband is a tailor. He would like to buy a few sewing machines for his shop with the loan.

The other group members are; Husna B. who makes and sells flowers; Walayat B. wants to buy her husband a cycle; Nusrat I. sells cloth.These women are neighbors and support each other in their endeavors.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nazia B. and I am a group leader of four other women. I am also a mother of three boys; two attend school and one, who is too young for school, stays at home. My husband works at a local hospital as support staff and I sell cloth. I travel to the city of Peshawar, which is famous for its inexpensive and good quality clothes, and buy cloth for my clothing sales. I would like to purchase additional cloth with this loan.

The other women in my group are requesting a loan for the following uses: Parween S. will use the loan to buy her son cardboard, Razia B. is borrowing money for her husband who is a construction worker, Kanwal B.’s husband wants this loan to buy cardboard and gum and Balqees B. will invest in her business.

loans.use: Buy cloth for the clothing sales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
For over 5 years, Richard, a resident of Mukono, has been buying charcoal and firewood from Masindi and selling them in Kampala. He is the same person who won the tender of supplying these fuel sources to Uganda Christian University in Mukono and this is the third year he is running the tender.

Richard is 39 years old and married with a two-year-old daughter, having lost his 10-year-old son last November. He also has one nephew in his care.

Before the loans, Richard could not run the tender whose payments are not instant as well as supplying Kampala but now business is smooth. His dream is to buy his own truck for transportation as well as to build a house on the plot he bought recently. At least most of the materials for construction are on his site. He is really thankful.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal and firewood for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Balqees' Group

texts.en:
My name is Balqees BibiI, the group leader. I am a widow from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I have five children. After my husband’s death, my sons undertook the responsibility to earn money for the family. They manufacture iron gates and therefore need a loan to buy iron in bulk.

The other women in my group would like a loan for the following uses; Shokat B. will buy wood , Zohra B. also needs to buy iron in bulk, Nusrat is borrowing money so her husband can buy a rickshaw and Kishwer B. would like to purchase a sewing machine.

I have known these women for many years and completely trust them. A small loan can bring big changes to our lives.

loans.use: Buy iron in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn M., 27, is a widow with one child. She lives with her old father in Sa Ang, which is located in Kandal province in Cambodia. She works in a factory and can earn about $3 per day. She has one son who is too young to enroll in school. She would like to request a loan to cure her father, who is sick; additionaly, she would use the loan to buy fertilizer, fuel for a pump, and pesticide to kill insects in order to make her rice field more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, fuel and pesticide.

loans.name: Abigeal

texts.en: Abigeal, 40, is married with 5 children. Two have completed secondary level, 2 are in secondary school, and 1 is in primary school. She has three years of business experience selling used clothes, locally known as “mivumba,” to various markets and trading centers. This has benefited her by allowing her to pay school fees for her children as well as to buy household items. She has a dream of one day opening up a shop selling used clothes to avoid the daily movements.

loans.use: Abigeal intends to buy more used clothes with the loan.

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nighat B.. I am a widow with five children; three boys and two girls. Both of my daughters are married and two of the boys are working. One son attends school. I sell various hair oils from my house. I want to expand my oils business and am requesting a loan for this purpose.

My group members have been together for the past three years. They are requesting the loan to use as follows: Jameela B. sells cloth and would like to increase her inventory. Bushra B. is borrowing money for her husband who supplies construction materials. Mukhtar B. will buy toys. Rani B. will buy a sewing machine with her share of loan.

loans.use: Buy hair oils in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en: Jolly  has been able to pay school fees for her 8 children using profits from the sale of produce like bananas and maize to traders in Bushenyi. And of her children, 1 has completed a diploma course, 4 are still in secondary school and 3 are still at primary level. She is 39 years old with a business experience of 10 years. Her dream is to open a stall in the trading centre for her produce.

loans.use: to open a stall in the trading centre to sell her produce

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Residing in Cotonou for more than twenty years, Mrs. Madeleine K. is originally from the town of Ketou in the Plateau Department, where she was born around 1964. She is a married mother of four children, whose schooling and support she is responsible for. A retailer of food products for over 20 years, she currently sells corn and akassa (fermented corn dough). For a little over a year now she hasn’t been able to maintain supply necessary to meet the needs of her customers considering strong demand. As an example, in January of 2008, demand was for 103 sacks while she had only 50 in stock. She is therefore seeking a loan which she needs to increase her stock in order to meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Installée à COTONOU depuis plus d'une vingtaine d'année, Dame K. Madeleine est originaire de KETOU dans le département du PLATEAU où elle a vu le jour vers les années 1964. Mariée, elle est mère de 4 enfants dont elle assure la scolarité et le suivi. Revendeuse de produits vivriers depuis plus de 20ans, elle vend actuellement du maïs et de l’AKASSA (pâte de maïs bouillie). Depuis un peu plus d’un an, elle n’arrive plus à disposer du stock nécessaire pour satisfaire sa clientèle compte tenu de la forte demande. A titre d’exemple, en janvier 2008 la demande était de 103 sacs alors qu’elle n’en avait que 50 dans comme stock. Pour cela elle sollicite ce prêt dont elle a tant besoin pour augmenter son stock afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.

loans.use: Purchase of 53 sacks of corn.

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Mrs. Khim N., 52 years old, is a housewife who takes care of six children. Three of her children contribute about $6 a day to the family income by working in the garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Prak Khen, is a motorcycle taxi driver and earns about $2 a day. They live in the Khpup Veng Village in Kandal Province.

She is now requesting a loan of $500 to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her husband’s transportation. This loan will also help to pay for her children’s school fees and daily living expenses.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle for her husband's transportation

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nasreen B. and I am a group leader of three other women. I have eight children; four boys and four girls. My husband is sick and cannot work. I operate a cycle rental from my home and currently own five cycles for this purpose. I want to purchase additional cycles so that my income can rise. I have invested two previous loans into my business. The additional profits enabled me to marry one of my daughters this past year and purchase a refrigerator for my house.

The other group members would use the loan as follows: Razia B. is borrowing for her husband’s CD and mobile phones business. Parween’s son wants to buy cardboard. Shazia will invest her share of the loan in her husband’s grocery store.

loans.use: Purchase bicycles

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Rooslan

texts.en:
Rooslan is married with a 16-year-old daughter. He and his family live in Uzhgorod, Ukraine. Rooslan rents an office and sells cell phones, accessories and offers cell phone repair services. His merchandise is relatively affordable and good quality. Rooslan provides good service in a timely manner and all his clients are very satisfied with the quality of his work. His wife helps him with the business. Her participation helps him to be mobile and flexible. Rooslan has been in this business for 6 years. Currently, his monthly profit is about $600.

Rooslan is very focused and determined. He is grateful for the loans he has received from Nadiya Ukraine, which have helped him expand his business. Today Rooslan is requesting a loan of $800 so that he can re-supply his inventory and purchase additional items at wholesale prices. The loan will benefit Rooslan’s business by keeping it competitive and promoting further growth in order to continue providing necessary income for him and his family. Also, the profits generated will allow Rooslan to pay his daughter’s college fees, which would otherwise consume a big portion of the family budget.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of his mobile phone store

loans.name: Muzira Twimukye Group

texts.en: Dezilanta is the chairperson of Muzira Twimukye group. She is 42 years and has 7 children of whom one is married, one is in senior 6 vacation, one is already in college, two are attending secondary school, while two are still in primary. She sells used clothes in markets, a business she has run for 2 years. She is our client and the loans she has received have benefited her in permitting her to buy more clothes for sale, hence being able to pay school fees for her children. She has also been able to create other income-generating activities like the sale of bananas. Her dream is to see all her children complete their education and attain good jobs.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two children and lives in Mukachevo. Mariya sells cosmetics and has been in this trade for 12 years. Her high-quality merchandise has always been in demand. Mariya’s business has been growing with remarkable stability and consistency. However, Mariya believes that now is a good time for further expansion. 

Currently, Mariya has $600 in profit each month, which is not quite enough for her to open a new vending location and stock it with inventory. She is requesting a loan of $800 to help her expand to another location. Mariya tries to keep her customers in mind and has managed to get better products, provide good customer service, and a larger market share. Mariya hopes this focus on her customers and commitment to business will help her business become even more successful.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
Mrs. Kuy Som O., 53, is a rice farmer in the Or Som Buo Village in Kompong Tom Province. She earns about $2 a day and has six children, three of whom are married. One son, Mr. Sem Sokchea, is a garment worker who earns about $2 a day, while another son, Mr. Sem Kem San, is a student; the rest are farmers. Mrs S. O.'s husband, Mr. Sem S., is a farmer and boatman. He earns about $4 a day.

She now requests a loan of $1000 to increase her working capital in rice farming and buy a fishing boat to create a fishing career for her husband. Because of her business, she now can further her child’s study and support her family’s living expenses.

loans.use: To increase her working capital in rice farming and buy a fishing boat to create a fishing career for her husband

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
I am Nusrat B., the group leader. I am a mother of two sons, both of whom attend school. The elder son is in grade six and the younger is in grade four. My husband and I sell cloth to various shops in Lahore where we live. It is the second largest city in Pakistan. He also travels to another city, Peshawar, which is known for cheap and good quality clothing and buys cloth from there for the business. Our business is small and the income is just enough to meet household expenses. We want to increase our income with this loan so that we can continue sending our kids to school and put food on our table.

The other group members would like to use the loan as stated: Shakila B. is borrowing the money for her husband who wants to buy an air pump. Maqsoodan B. sells cloth and would like to increase her inventory. Nasreen B. wants to make improvements to her small restaurant.

loans.use: Buy cloth in bulk

loans.name: Rukia Nianjema Group

texts.en:
Rukia M., age 46, is married and has 4 children (ages 18, 15, 13 and 11). She has a small stand at the market, a business which she began 8 years ago. She works from 6am to 8pm daily and has managed to make a monthly profit of about US$ 44.

In the past, Rukia has taken out three loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand her business, and she started a fish business as well. She hopes for a new loan to further expand both businesses. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in selling fish, running a beauty salon, a shop and selling food.

In the picture Rukia is 1st on the right

loans.use: to expand available business capital

loans.name: Esther Tanzanite Group

texts.en:
Esther A. , age 30, has got a child of ten. She has a beauty salon which she began 4 years ago. She works from 7:30am to 10pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of around US$ 258.

In the past, Esther has taken out two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy salon equipment. She hopes for a new loan to start a secretarial service. Esther will share this loan with her subgroup members who have shops, sell coconuts and have a butchery.

In the picture Esther is in the middle back row.

loans.use: to buy a printer and start a secretarial service

loans.name: Esher Tanzanite Group

texts.en:
Esther A. , age 30, has got a child of ten years. She has a salon which she began 4 years ago. She works from 7.30am to 10pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of around US$258.

In the past, Esther has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy salon equipments. He hopes for a new loan to start a secretarial service. Esther will share this loan with her subgroup members selling shops, coconut fruits and butchery.

In the picture Esher is in the middle back row

loans.use: to buy a printer and start a secretarial service

loans.name: Bakyala Kwekulakulanya Group

texts.en: Sarah is the chairperson of Bakyala Kwekulakulanya group that sits in Buikwe. She is 54 years and married with 7 children as she raises 8 additional children. She has had a retail shop business in the Buikwe, Ajija trading centre for 6 years. She is our client of over 10 years and the loans have helped her from the start of her shop. This has enabled her to pay her children’s school fees and cater for home needs. Her dream is to see her retail shop transform into a wholesale shop and due to her determination, she will achieve it.

loans.use: Sarah plans to buy more sugar, soap, salt, and eggs for her retail shop.

loans.name: Mbowa Teddy's Group

texts.en: Teddy, the group leader, is 49 years old and married with 8 children as she looks after 4 grand children. She is a farmer having banana, beans and maize plantations and is a business woman involved in buying and selling coffee and dried fish. Her last born child is in his senior 6 vacation while the grandchildren are in nursery and primary school. Without the loans, she would not have been able to expand her business enough to pay the school fees and look after her family, so she is very grateful.

loans.use: Teddy's intention is to buy more coffee and dried fish for sale as well as to employ manpower on her plantations.

loans.name: Kaddu Mukasa's Group

texts.en: Kaddu is a fisherman, a banana plantation farmer, and a businessman involved in buying and selling coffee. His main job is fishing in Kiyindi, Buikwe where he has three boats. He has been our client of one and a half years and the loans have really helped him in all his jobs.  With his previous loan, he was able to buy a new boat engine that helped him pay school fees as well as start a poultry business for his wife at home. He plans to buy another engine with this loan to fulfill his dream of constructing rental houses in Buikwe town.

loans.use: Kaddu plans to buy another boat engine as well as buy coffee and chicken mash.

loans.name: Namuleme Immaculate's Group

texts.en: Immaculate,52, is a widow left to care for her nine children.  She now also looks after four grandchildren. For the last 10 years, she has been preparing a local brew called “waragi” from her home, which she sells wholesale to neighboring towns while some customers drink from her home. She also has a retail shop at her home that was opened using the savings from the sell of waragi. She has been our client of over 10 years and with us, she has been able to pay her children’s school fees promptly. With this loan, she intends to renovate her house by providing shelter for her customers as well as secure some fees for her daughter that is seating senior 6 this year.

loans.use: To buy cement and bricks and to employ manpower for renovating her house for business.  Also, to buy more sugar, bread and cakes for her retail shop.

loans.name: Edina

texts.en: Edina is a 33-year-old woman from Hlapčevići, a small village near Visoko. She is  married  and her husband has a full-time job. His monthly salary is about US$ 500. They have 2 children, one month and  7 years old. Edina does farming and she will use this loan in the amount of  US$ 1,150 for buying  material for planting. With selling the crops she raises, Edina thinks that she will ensure additional income for her  family.

loans.use: Buying material for planting

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: Fatmata is 35 years old and married with 3 children.  Although her husband is employed, his salary is insufficient to meet the family’s expenses.  With four loans from SMT, Fatmata was able to increase her stock of palm and nut oil.  She is now requesting a loan of $700 to purchase 120 gallons of palm and nut oil.  She would like to sell them on wholesale.

loans.use: Fatmata has a goal of selling her oil on wholesale.   Her loan from SMT would start her on the path to achieving that goal.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en: Rugiatu started her business 4 years ago and was selling a few vegetables.  With the loans from SMT, she diversified her business by including spices, fish and other items and was able to rent a stall in the town market of Makeni.  Rugiatu is 37 years old and is happy with the program and would like to continue borrowing from SMT to expand her business.  She is, therefore, requesting a loan of $350.  Rugiatu is married with 4 children.

loans.use: Rugiatu has learned the value of diversifying her stock of food items for sale and needs a loan from Kiva to further diversify and expand her business.

loans.name: Alema

texts.en:
Alema was born in 1976 and she lives together with her husband in Hlapčevići, near the town of Visoko. Her husband is a professional soldier and his monthly salary is about US$ 925.

Alema has requested this loan in the amount of US$ 925 in order to buy a few sheep. She wants to expand her business with sheep-raising as she has all the right conditions for sheep breeding. Alema thinks that this way, she will secure additional money for their 2 children who are 5 and 8 years old.

loans.use: Buying a few sheep to raise

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is 25 years old and married with one child.  Salamatu continued running her small business after getting married. Her husband is unemployed and she sells palm oil, wheat flour and other food items in the market in Markeni town of Sierra Leone. She said it was because of the loan capital from SMT that she was able to increase her stock and profit.  Salamatu is one of SMT’s best clients who meets her loan obligations on time.  She is now requesting more loans to expand her business.

loans.use: Salamatu is a young entrepreneur with a lot of potential.  She has a keen eye for business and is excited to take the next steps in expanding and diversifying her business.

loans.name: Selma

texts.en: Selma is a 41-year-old woman  from Križ, a small village near Visoko. She is not married  but she has  3 children 7, 8, and 10 years old. Selma sells  clothing at the market  and she can  earn about US$ 300 monthly. This is her  first loan  through MCO WWI in the amount of  US$ 925. Selma will invest it in clothes in order  to expand  her business  and earn  some  additional money.

loans.use: Invest in clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Munevera

texts.en: Munevera lives together  with her husband  in Križ, a small village near  Visoko. They have a stand at the market  and they sell clothes. Their monthly income is  not enough for  both of them  and  their  2 children  who are  9 and  10 years old. Munevera wants to invest  this loan  in the amount  of  US$ 925 in clothing  in order to  expand  the business  and secure  money for her family.

loans.use: Invest in clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Abu

texts.en: Abu is 49 years old and married with 5 children.  With all the children in school, Abu needs to have a good business to generate profit.  His previous loans from SMT enabled him increase his stock.  He is now requesting another loan of $350 to expand his business.

loans.use: Abu is in need of additional capital so that he can purchase additional bales of clothing for selling in his shop.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia B., a married mother of one child, lives in Vinogradovo, Ukraine. For the past three, she has run a small stand in selling fresh food, groceries, clothing, cleaning supplies, and hardware in a local outdoor market. Because Sylvia is a goal-oriented, smart, and communicative entrepreneur, her business is flourishing.

Today Sylvia has applied for a loan of $1200 U.S. dollars so she can open additional stands in other locations. She is confident that she will be able to pay the money back in full because always seeks out high quality products that sell. Her business provides an important source of income for her family, and she hopes to expand it.

loans.use: To buy groceries, clothing, and cleaning supplies for an outdoor stand

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina S. owns a small store in Berdyansk, a small port city in southern Ukraine, where she sells mainly groceries and children's clothing. Known for her honesty and business savvy, Valentina has applied for a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars and is confident that she'll be able to pay back every cent.

With the loan, Valentina intends to purchase more clothing inventory and d some repairs and remodeling in her store. She hopes that she'll be able to grow her business to establish a secure future for herself and her family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for a small store

loans.name: Maria Louisa

texts.en:
Maria Louisa is 32 years old. She has been a member of Juanito, a community bank, for three years. The community bank gives her confidence; since joining she has learned responsibility and punctuality.

Maria originally joined the bank to get a loan to be able to finish university; she has a teaching degree. She was unable to get a loan from other banks because they needed collateral. Now Maria has a business making curtains. She also sells a variety of home goods. Maria is planning to expand her business and start doing tailoring within the next year. For this, she plans to buy an industrial sewing machine.

Maria also enjoys working with children. She volunteers at the Santa Teresa Church working with orphans. She teaches classes and works to get them presents or treats on holidays. Her dream is to build an orphanage.

Maria needs a loan of $1,200, which she will use to buy an industrial sewing machine and other equipment to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy an industrial sewing machine and other equipment

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is 29 years and married with a child.  She sells ladies' and children’s clothes in the town of Magburaka in Sierra Leone, and has been running her business for the last 5 years.  She would now like to expand her business and is requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: Marie would like a loan to help her in the expansion of her business selling used clothing.

loans.name: Issa

texts.en: Issa S. is very grateful to Kiva.  With the loan from Kiva, he was able to make a profit, increase his stock of medicines and repair the roof of the family house.  He said, “It is humble to mention the benefit of the loan to my family, to those who provided the loan. The most important thing I have done with the profit from the loan is repair the roof of the family house."  Isa is very happy that the loan has enabled him to generate enough profit to do so.  He is now requesting another loan to expand his pharmacy further.

loans.use: Issa was extremely successful as a result of his first loan from Kiva and would appreciate the opportunity to take a second loan and continue his success.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is married with 4 children.  She sells plastic sandals in the market of Makeni town in Sierra Leone. She was retailing the sandals, but after her previous loans from SMT, she increased her stock and now sells on wholesale.  She would like to expand her business and is, therefore, requesting a loan of $1200.  Salamatu is 36 years old.

loans.use: Salamatu is a wholesaler of shoes and sandals in the Makeni market.  She needs additional capital to be able to purchase her goods in bulk for wholesaleing.

loans.name: Sayda Virginia

texts.es:
Three years ago, Sayda started selling ice cream and candy. Her husband was out of work at the time and could only find a job as a taxi driver, but his income was insufficient. Wanting to help with the household expenses, Sayda decided to start her business. Many children currently know about her establishment.

However, she does not have enough products to meet the children’s demands. For this reason, Sayda is requesting a loan of $475.00, which she is willing to repay back in 6 monthly installments, in order to purchase more products to offer to her customers. Furthermore, with her earnings, she will be able to move her family forward with the help of her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace tres años que Sayda comenzó a vender helados y dulces. Puesto que su esposo se quedó sin trabajo y lo que pudo conseguir fue como taxista. Sin embargo como con lo que gana no es suficiente. Fue por lo que Sayda con la voluntad para ayudar en los gastos de su casa, fue que comenzó con el negocio. Actualmente muchos niños conocen el establecimiento.

Sin embargo no cuenta con mercancía suficiente que demandan los niños. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Sayda podrá comprar más mercancía para ofrecerle a sus clientes. Además de que con las ganancias podrá sacar adelante a su familia con la ayuda de su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim S. is 35 years old and married with 4 children. He sews dresses and men’s gowns mainly in Makeni town.  With the previous loans, he was able to buy a sewing machine and some materials.  Ibrahim also trains school drop outs who are interested in sewing skills.  He is interested in running his business as a training center for tailoring, as well as for production.  He is, therefore, requesting for a loan of $700 to purchase 3 sewing machines and materials.

loans.use: Ibrahim wants to continue to contribute to the youth in his community and needs additional sewing machines and supplies to continue offering his apprenticeship training activities.

loans.name: Ya Sinnah

texts.en: Ya Sinnah runs a small grocery shop in Makeni town, which she expanded with the loans from SMT.  She plans to increase her stock and, in the future, rent a shop in the market.  She is requesting a loan of $700 to pursue her dreams.  Ya Sinnah is 41 years old and has 9 children.  Her income contributes a lot towards family expenses, especially school requirements.

loans.use: Ya Sinnah has a small grocery store that is experiencing excellent growth and profits.  She needs additional capital to continue to supplement her business as it moves towards becoming sustainable.

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama sells her food items in Makeni town of Sierra Leone.  She uses her friend's veranda to place her goods.  With 4 children and an unemployed husband, she needs to increase her stock to generate more income.  She is, therefore, requesting a loan of $700 for this purpose.  Adama is 36 years old.

loans.use: Adama needs additional money to help her purchase enough stock to sell and generate sufficient profits.

loans.name: Noemi's Group

texts.en:
Gloria, Idelfonza, and Noemí are members of the community bank Juanito. Gloria and Noemi have belonged to the bank for one year, while Idelfonza has been a member for three. Through the community bank, they have learned to avoid sickness and how to care for their children in addition to how to manage their businesses.

Gloria is 30 years old. She is a single mother and has two children. Gloria started her business selling potatoes from a cart near the local market. Now, she travels to fields outsiD. of the city and buys potatoes in bulk, which she then sells to others in the market. Occasionally, she transports potatoes to Lima. Gloria also has a field where she grows her own potatoes. In her free time Gloria cleans hotels.

Idelfonza is 51 years old. She is married and has five children. Idelfonza travels to different markets in the region of Ayacucho where she buys meats, cheeses, and grains, which she sells in the markets of Ayacucho.

Noemi is 27 years old. She is a single mother and has two children. Her 8 year old daughter likes to sing. Noemi has a store where she sells food staples such as rice, flour, and sugar. The store is located in her home. Noemi also buys blankets maD. in Ayacucho and sells them in the district of Tambo.

Gloria, Idelfonza, and Noemí need a loan of $925, which they will use to buy potatoes, meat, and a refrigerator.

Their dreams are to own a home, give their children a good education, buy land, and help Noemi’s daughter become a successful artist.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, meat, and a refrigerator

loans.name: Santigie

texts.en: Santigie sells second hand clothes in Makeni town of Sierra Leone.  He is 38 years old and is a school drop out who needs to earn income to support his parents.  With previous loans from SMT, he rented a space in the open market to run his business. The business is the main source of income for the family.  He is, therefore, requesting a loan to expand the business and, in the future, rent a better space.  Santigie is married with a child.

loans.use: Santigie is faced with supporting many dependants and needs to supplement his business enough so that it can produce the profits needed.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed was a trader.  With the previous loans, he established himself in the market of Makeni and rented a space for the business. Mohamed also decided to sell only t-shirts, which he found have a huge market among the youth.  Like many other youth, who have less opportunity for education, S. dropped out of school due to lack of tuition fees.  Mohamed wishes to expand his business and is requesting for a loan of $700.

loans.use: Mohamed has decided to specialize in selling t-shirts that are popular amongst the youth, and needs capital to purchase the latest fashions and meet his customers' demands.

loans.name: Delia's Group

texts.en:
Rocio, Delia, and Alejandra are all members of the community bank Juanito. From their involvement in the community bank they have learned to be responsible and punctual, and how to avoid getting sick.

Rocio is 24 years old. She lives with her partner and four year old daughter. She is studying social work at the local university. Rocio sells cosmetics from a catalogue to her friends and family in order to help pay for school. Rocio also has a car, which she uses as a taxi to bring in extra income.

Delia is 28 years old. She makes and sells handicrafts, such as small rag dolls. She buys materials from the city of Lima where prices are lower, and sells her products in bulk to stores. In addition, Delia owns a motorcycle taxi.

Alejandra is 28 years old. She is married and has three children. Alejandra embroiders weavings; she buys weavings, embroiders them, and does other finishing work. She sells her work to established clients in Lima.

Rocio, Delia, and Alejandra need loans of $1,050, which they will use to buy perfumes, creams, fabrics, wool, weavings, and repairing their motorcycle taxi.

Rocio, Delia, and Alejandra dream of finishing school, having a stable business, improving their children’s lives, and owning a home.

loans.use: To buy perfumes, creams, fabrics, wool, weavings, and repair their motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama K. sells African cotton materials in the market town of Makeni in Sierra Leone.  Adama said, with her previous loans, her business volume increased by 50%.  Her business is the main source of income for the family.  Her husband also does some business to support the family, but at a very small scale.  Adama is requesting for a loan of $700 to expand her business.  Adama is 33 years old and married with 3 children.

loans.use: Adama would like to expand her business of selling African print cotton fabric and needs a loan from Kiva to be able to achieve her goals.

loans.name: José Arturo

texts.es:
José Arturo studied computer sciences, learning how to repair computers. After finishing his studies, he started working at a private company; however, his income was not sufficient for him to be independent. He no longer wanted to be a burden on his parents. José Arturo is currently married, which is why he is so enthusiastic about making his business grow, hoping to one day set it up in a business space.

Nevertheless, what José needs to do first is keep his customers and offer them first-rate service. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of $675.00 USD, which he is willing to repay in 6 monthly installments, in order to purchase tools and computer parts so that he can offer his customers better services and keep them coming back for more. With your help, José will be able to save enough money so that his children will not lack anything they need.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

José Arturo, estudió una carrera de sistemas, en dónde aprendió a reparar problemas a las computadoras. Después de terminar su carrera comenzó a trabajar en una empresa. Sin embargo lo que ganaba no era suficiente para poder ser independiente. Puesto que José deseaba ya no ser una carga para sus padres. Actualmente José Arturo ya se encuentra casado y es por eso que tiene más entusiasmo para poder crecer su negocio y algún día estabilizarlo con un local.

Sin embargo lo primero que tiene que hacer José, es conservar a sus clientes y ofrecerles un servicio de primera. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $675 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero José podrá comprar sus herramientas y refacciones para poder brindarle un mejor servicio a sus clientes y que estos regresen a su empresa. Con tu ayuda José podrá hacer un ahorro para que no le falte nada a los hijos que desea tener.

loans.use: Purchase of tools

loans.name: Tania's Group

texts.en:
Clara, Tania, and Ruth are from the community of Rumichaca, located 15 minutes outsiD. of the city of Ayacucho. They have been members of the community bank Rumichaca for six months.

Clara is 63 years old. She is married and has four children, two of whom live with her. Clara grows parsley, cilantro, and other agricultural products that she sells in Ayacucho.
