Teddy N. is currently operating a clinic business and wants a loan to stock more drugs. Rose N. operates a business selling matooke and wants to open up another business in another location. Harriet N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to add to her business.

loans.use: To start a dairy business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer

loans.name: Kireka C1 E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Victor N.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to rent bigger premises. Victor is 32 years old and is divorced. She has 2 children aged 6 and 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Victor makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to venture into another business. Victor has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Victor is joined in her small group by Grace N., Hanifah N., Annet N., and Sara N.. Grace N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to expand to wholesale selling. Hanifah N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to open up another restaurant in a different location. Annet N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to purchase more braids and weaves. Sara N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth fabric.

loans.use: To add to restaurant business and expand it

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nayamt Allah

texts.en: Nayamt Allah lives with his own family in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single, and he has a retail shop. He has been involved in this business for more than 2 years. He has a good number of customers but he wants to expand his business. He wants to take out an individual loan to complete his stock and make a better income to support his family and build up a good business for himself for the future.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Nansana Church A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Regina S.. She is currently in the business of farming and is requesting a loan to buy seeds, and hire labor and transport for her produce. Regina is 45 years old and is a widow. She has 7 children ranging from age 19 to 30 and her children go to school. Each week, Regina makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to rent a store where she can sell her produce. Regina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to set up a banana plantation and the loan was paid back on time.

Regina is joined in her small group by Janat Wasajja, Prossy S., Annet N., and Mary N.. Janat Wasajja has a business selling jewelry and wants to purchase more materials. Prossy S. is currently operating a business selling fish and wants a loan to add capital and buy fish directly at the seashore. Annet N. operates a public pay phone business and wants to purchase airtime cards and another phone. Mary N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add stock to her shop.

loans.use: To add capital to farming business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nansana Church B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Gertrude K.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Gertrude is 42 years old and is a widow. She has 4 children ranging from age 18 to 26 and her children go to school. Each week, Gertrude makes approximately UGX 75000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start up a piggery business. Gertrude has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to purchase clothes and bed sheets and the loan was paid back on time.

loans.name: Marieta Nzisa

texts.en:
Description
Marietta Nzisa is 30 years old. She’s married with one child and is expecting her second in February.  Marietta started her business in the year 2006 after finishing her computer course, in one of computer colleges in the city, she then approached her mother with a request of a loan to start her own business since she did not like to be asking her mother for money to buy things like creams, sanitary towels etc.  Her mother loaned her Ksh 80,000, and with this she bought three computers and rented a stall at Kasarani a town on the outskirts of Nairobi, providing internet and photocopying services.

Due to the popularity and demand of computer services, Marietta wants to add three more computers so as to cope with her growing number of customers.  Currently her loyal customers must wait 30 minutes to get access to one computer.  The wait sometimes makes some customers leave, and this pains Marietta greatly.  She is therefore requesting a loan amounting to Ksh 85,000. Given this loan Marietta will be able to purchase the three brand new computers, a landmark for Marietta since she will be able to provide quick and efficient service.  She will also be training at least one student who wants to be trained in a computer course so that that instead of going all the way to town they will save by training at her place.

Marietta thanks the Kiva lenders in advance.  The repayment period for this loan is 10-12 months.

loans.use: Purchase  Three Computers.

loans.name: Mariam's Tujitume. Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 27 years old and is married. She owns a small pharmacy, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7:30am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales. Mariam now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Saida, Rehema and Salma, who have businesses seling food.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hadeesa's Group

texts.en:
I am Hadeesa B. from Arifwala, a small town in Pakistan. I am the mother of two kids who are small and do not attend school currently but will hopefully attend school in the near future. I am borrowing for the second time from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan.

My husband works at a transport company and wants to buy a rickshaw. He will give this rickshaw for rent to his brother. This way both will mutually benefit from the profits.

I would like to borrow in a group that includes: Shazia B., who will use the loan to expand her vegetable shop; Shabana B., who intends to use her share of loan to expand her vegetable and legume business; and Fatima B., who needs this loan for her family’s mobile phone store.

As this is a group loan we mutually accept responsibility of this loan.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw and expand family businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
I was married six years ago and have three kids. All of my kids are under 5 years old, and only the eldest attends school.

My husband sells vests and socks in a busy nearby market. I would like to have a loan for the improvement of his business. He will buy vests and socks in large quantities, which will save on cost per item and will be cheaper as a result.

I am a group leader of a few other women. Sakina B. is acquiring the loan for her husband, who trades various spices. Rukhsana B. needs this loan for her used-items business. Jameela B. is borrowing for the first time and needs the loan for her son’s motorcycle rental business.

These women are very hardworking entrepreneurs and play an important role in getting income for their families. I feel that if every one of us starts helping each other, our community can grow and improve.

loans.use: Buy vests and socks in a large quantity

loans.name: Asha's Tujitume. Group

She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Asha, Habiba and Rahma, who also sell food.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.name: Halima's Group

texts.en:
My name is Halima M.. I am from a small city, Arifwala, Pakistan. I have four kids: three boys and one girl.

Last year, I borrowed 15000 ($250) for my husband‘s crockery business from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. He sells crockery on his cart. This time, we need another loan for the same business.

I have four other women in my loan group. Raheela N. needs this loan for her hosiery business. Kaneez S. , who is borrowing for the second time, will again invest in her son’s auto repair workshop. Safia L. requires this loan for her husband to start a grocery store. Rafia S. will invest her share of the loan in her father’s grocery store. I have known these women for a long time and completely trust them.

loans.use: Expand crockery business

texts.en:

One of my sons is a medical rep, who supplies medicine to various shops in the city. Last year we borrowed from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan and invested in his business. This year, we want another loan for him. He will use the loan to buy more medicine and hence supply more.

My group members who are in need of loans are: Shugufta B., who needs this loan to invest in her family’s shoe factory; Shumaila B., who will use her share of the loan to improve her vests and socks sales; and Nazia B., who requires this loan to buy a rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one and another’s loans. If one member does not repay, the others are responsible.

loans.use: Buy medicines in bulk for medical supply business

She is married with four children; three work in a factory, and one is a student.  She and the Village Bank would like to request the loan of $2,575 in order to buy more vegetables to sell every day. All of the people in the picture are the borrowers, except for the two women standing under the tree and the woman who has a child in her arms (they are the owners of the house).

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Mrs. Ya F., 52 years old, is a cake seller in the Bei Village in the Chrung Comres I Sangkat in Phnom Penh City. She takes care of eleven children and earns about $3 a day. Her husband, Mr. Rim Ly, is a 59-year-old motorcycle taxi driver who earns about $2 a day. Her son, Mr.Ly Smeanglor, a bricklayer, and her daughter, Ms. Ly Mari, a garment worker, earn about $2 a day each. The other children are students. She previously successfully concluded a loan with HKL.

To increase income for her family, she is now requesting a loan of $1000 to expand her inventory of cakes. This loan will also help to pay for her children’s school fees and daily living expenses.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of cakes for sale.

Her husband is a hair dresser. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Margret is joined in her small group by Madina N., Teo M., Rose N., and Brendah N.. Madina N. has a business running a market stall and wants to add stock. Teo M. is currently operating a poultry keeping business and wants a loan to purchase more chicks and feed. Rose N. operates a business selling matooke and wants to start purchasing in bulk. Brendah N. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to buy a hair dryer.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San R. K., 48 years old, sells dried fish in the Kilomet 6 market in Phnom Penh City. She takes care of seven children, two of whom contribute about $4 a day to the family by working in the garment factory;  the rest are students. Her husband, Mr. Tes Ya, drives a motorcycle taxi and earns about $2 a day.

She is now asking for a loan of $1000 to expand her dried fish-selling business and further her children’s studies. She thanks Kiva and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To expand her dried fish-selling business

loans.name: El

texts.en:
Mrs. El R. and her husband, Mr. Nos Him, are dried fish sellers. They both earn about $10 a day and take care of seven children, all of whom are enrolled in school. She lives with her family in the Bei Village in the Chrung Chumres I Sangkat in Phnom Penh City. Because of her business, she can help her children to go to school and pay her family’s living expenses.

In order to help her husband support their large family, R. now requests a loan of $1000 to increase her inventory of dried fish and further her children’s studies. She appreciates Kiva and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of dried fish for her business

loans.name: Sos

texts.en:
Mrs. Sos K. V. and her husband, Mr. Math Sales, are fish sellers and live in the Bei Village in the Chrung Chumres Sangkat in Phnom Penh City. They earn about $8 a day and take care of four children, one of whom contributes about $2 a day to the family by working in the garment factory. 

Previously, they successfully concluded a loan with HKL, and now request a loan of $500 to more efficiently expand their fish-selling business.

loans.use: To more efficiently expand their fish-selling business.

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
I am Zahida P. N., a widow of an age of 50 years. I was born in a small city, Okara, but moved to a mid-sized city, Multan, Pakistan, with my family. I have three kids: two boys and one girl.

I make various items out of fresh flowers, such as bouquets and necklaces. I am borrowing so that I can improve my business. I have spent all my life in poverty but do not want the same fate to befall my kids, therefore I work very hard in my business.

There are four other women in my loan group. Bushra B. is borrowing for her fruit business. Iqbal B. will invest her share of the loan in her family’s garment business. Rubina B. is borrowing for her brother, who is a salesman and supplies various grocery items.

loans.use: Improve current flower business

loans.name: Shakooran's Group

texts.en:
I am Shakooran S.. I am from Multan, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. I have lived in this city for the last 35 years. I am married and the mother of eight: five boys and three girls. One of my sons is an electrician and wants a loan for his electric goods store.

I would like to borrow with a group of several other women. Abida B. sells rugs and mats. Sakina B. is borrowing to buy a rickshaw. Nosheen B. will fix her family’s rickshaw with her share of the loan. Rashida B. is acquiring the loan for her tailoring business. I wish these women a bright future for their families.

loans.use: Expand electric goods store

loans.name: Ghafooran's Group

texts.en:
I am the leader of a small group of women. My husband and son both operate separate bike rental stores. My son wants to buy an additional bike for his store.

Earlier, when my husband got sick and could not work , I had to face many hardships. I started operating a small canteen in a local school. I do not work any more because my husband has recovered and is back to work.

There are a few other women in need of loans: Nasira, Salma and Farzana all run separate boutiques. All these women work very hard to get income for their families and I request you lend to us immediately.

loans.use: Buy an additional bike for bike rental business

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
My name is Zubaida R.. I am from Arifwala, a small metropolis in Pakistan. I am 30, married, and the mother of four: two boys and two girls. My husband is a rickshaw driver and he wants to buy an additional rickshaw. He will give this additional rickshaw for rent to supplement his income.

I request loans for my group members also. Mussarat B. will invest her share of the loan in her family’s restaurant. Sakina B. and Manzoora M. both are borrowing for their lumber yard.

loans.use: Buy an additional rickshaw

loans.name: Nafees' Group

texts.en:
I am Nafees B. and I live in a one-room, mud-brick house with my family here in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I have three kids: two boys and one girl, all aged between one and five years old.

My husband is a butcher and sells meat. He wants to buy a few additional cattle for this purpose.

My group members are in need of loans also. Zubaida M. is borrowing for her family’s shoes business. Kaneez B. trades bamboo. Sughran B. sells bangels. Shahbaz B. makes and sells carpets.

loans.use: Expand butcher shop

loans.name: Janet

Janet A. is married to a pastor and has 4 children.  Janet sells second hand clothing in a small fishing village just outside of Cape Coast called Elmina.  She is requesting a loan of $475 to buy additional clothing so she can expand her business.  She hopes this loan will increase her profits and she’ll be able to provide additional income to her family.

Janet is also a member of a lending group called “Nkor Ma Ahoto Traders”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing so she can expand her business.

loans.name: Wakimese D(Iii) Group

Her husband is self employed. Each week, Edith makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Edith is joined in her small group by Betty K., Hadijah N., Cate N. and Teddy N.. Betty K. has a business in clothing sales and wants to boost business. Hadijah N. is currently operating a business selling fish and wants a loan to add capital. Cate N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to buy more braids and weaves. Teddy N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a babylock machine.

loans.name: Wakimese D(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Teddy N.. She is currently in the business of running a market stall and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Teddy is 45 years old and is a widow. She has 4 children ranging from age 20 to 27. Each week, Teddy makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her market stall business.

Teddy is joined in her small group by Fatuma A., Justine N., Cissy N., and Lillian N.. Fatuma A. has a business running a market stall and wants to add capital. Justine N. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Cissy N. operates a retail shop business and wants to buy a second fridge. Lillian N. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more furniture.

loans.use: To boost market stall business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys M. is married to a carpenter and has 3 children.  She walks around the docks, in a small fishing village just outside of Cape Coast, selling cassava dough.  Cassava dough is mixed with corn dough to prepare a popular Ghanaian dish called “banku”.  She is requesting $525 to buy cassava dough in bulk so she can get a discount from the wholesaler.  

Gladys is also a member of a lending group called “Nkor Ma Ahoto Traders”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy cassava dough in bulk so she can get a discount from the wholesaler.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is a 51-year-old mother of 5 children. She works and lives in southern Lebanon, in Tyre.
Sabah is a widow, so she has to provide for her family. As such, she sells clothes. This is the fourth time Sabah  has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, she is planning to buy new merchandise to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To purchase new merchandise to sustain and develop her business

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate A. is married to a police man and has 5 children, 3 of whom she is currently taking care of.  Kate is a fishmonger who buys fish from local fishermen and sells them to customers.  She is requesting a loan of $525 to buy more fish as well as equipment to cook and smoke the fish.

Kate is also a member of a lending group called “Nkor Ma Ahoto Traders”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy more fish as well as equipment to cook and smoke the fish.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama G. works on the docks of the Elmina fishing village.  She is married to a security guard and has 2 children.  To help support her family she buys fish from fishermen and sells them to her customers.  She is requesting a loan of $525 to buy more fish as well as equipment to cook and smoke the fish.

Ama is the group leader of a lending group called “Nkor Ma Ahoto Traders”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy more fish as well as equipment to cook and smoke the fish.

loans.name: Masanda A(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Aisha N.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair oils and chemicals. Aisha is 33 years old and is married. She has 2 children ranging from age 6 months to 2.5 years old. Each week, Aisha makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Aisha is joined in her small group by Ruth N., Sarah N., Pauline K., and Justine N.. Ruth N. has a business running a bar and wants to purchase a fridge. Sarah N. is currently operating a stone quarrying business and wants a loan to add capital. Pauline K. operates a business of livestock farming and wants to purchase livestock feed. Justine N. is currently in the business of running a canteen and is requesting a loan to start a charcoal business.

loans.use: To add working capital to salon business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
E. Justina is in the fish business, a fish monger to be precise. Currently her husband is outside the country and they have 2 children. Previously she sold saucepans but business went bad and she has now moved to selling fish which is doing well at the moment.

She is asking for $275 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.name: Dikassofor 2 Group

texts.fr:
After repaying our first loan from Kiva, we considered enlarging our business, which is breeding broiler chickens. We thus increased the number of members of our group so we could expand our work and employ more people, creating jobs for youth who don’t know what to do. We have therefore decided to increase production by doubling our original capacity. In this way we will contribute to the fight against poverty and participate in the development of our community. Our product sells as well in the city as it does in the village and the earnings from our first loan will be reinvested with the money we are now asking for from Kiva to renew our project.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Après avoir réussi à rembourser le premier prêt que nous avons reçu de Kiva, nous avons envisagé d'agrendir notre activité qui est l'élevage de poulets de chaire. C'est ainsi donc que nous avons augmenter le nombre de membre duè groupement pour que le travail puisse être élargi et employer plus de personnes, créant ainsi des emplois pour des jeunes qui ne savaient pas quoi faire. Nous avons donc décidé d'augmenter notre production en passant du simple au double de notre capacité première. c'est de cette façon que nous contibuons à la lutte contre la pauvreté et que nous participons au développement de notre communauté. Notre produit se vend aussi bien en ville qu'au village et ce que nous avions gagné lors du premier prêt sera réinvesti avec le fonds que nous demandons à Kiva pour le renouvellement de notre projet.

loans.use: Purchase of chicks, feed, and vaccines.

loans.name: Masanda A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Winnie Luyimbazzi. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to expand business. Winnie is 27 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 months to 7 years old and three of them go to school. Each week, Winnie makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a milk selling business.

Winnie is joined in her small group by Barbara N., Adrine A., Julian T., and Betty M.. Barbara N. has a business selling used clothes and wants to venture into new clothes. Adrine A. is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to increase stock. Julian T. operates a business of clothing sales and wants to boost business. Betty M. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items.

loans.use: To add capital to salon business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
A. Esther is a chop bar operator. She is married to a fisherman and has 5 children. Business is booming and her customer base is increasing so she wants to increase production and sales.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more maize, fish, oil palm fruit, tomatoes and other items.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more maize, fish, oil palm fruit, tomatoes etc.

loans.name: Nabaziza D(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Grace N.. She is currently in the business of bricks and is requesting a loan to boost business. Grace is 45 years old and is single. She has 3 children ranging from age 25 to 27. Each week, Grace makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to boost her stone quarrying business.

Grace is joined in her small group by Mariam N., Berna N., Becca N., and Eva Z.. Mariam N. has a business in stone quarrying and wants to buy and supply stones to others. Berna N. is currently operating a bar business and wants a loan to add furniture. Becca N. operates a business of clothing sales and wants to start selling bed sheets. Eva Z. is currently in the business of running a salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a second hair dryer.

loans.use: To add working capital to brick business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
B. Theresa is a trader who sells bags of rice; she also prepares a native food called 'wakye' for sale. She is married to a carpenter and has 3 children. She is asking for the loan to buy more bags of rice, vegetable oil, tin tomatoes and others.

She is asking for $252 as additional capital to buy the items.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy inventory.

loans.name: Nabaziza D(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Nalongo L.. She is currently in the business of making and selling snacks and is requesting a loan to expand business. Nalongo is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a civil servant. She has 4 children ranging from age 14 to 19 and her children go to school. Each week, Nalongo makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy food warmers.

Nalongo is joined in her small group by Sepiranza N., Margret B., Berna N., and Irene S.. Sepiranza N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to buy bigger saucepans. Margret B. is currently operating a stone quarrying business and wants a loan to add to her business. Berna N. operates a business in clothing sales and wants to purchase more clothes. Irene S. is currently in the business of running a drug shop and clinic and is requesting a loan to purchase a microscope.

loans.use: To purchase more baking flour, cooking oil and frying pans

loans.name: Agnes' Fanaka E Group

texts.en:
Agnes G., age 37, is married and has five children (ages 21, 19, 19,14 and 12). She sells sarongs, fruits and vegetables which she began one and half years ago. She works from 8am to 6pm daily making a monthly profit of about US$86.

In the past, Agnes has taken out three previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase her business. She hopes for a new loan to start selling fried fish. Agnes will share this loan with her subgroup members dealing in selling charcoal, poultry and wood.

In the picture Agnes is the only lady.

loans.use: To begin selling fried fish at her shop

loans.name: Kibibi's Msimamo Group

texts.en:
Kibibi S., age 47, is married and has six children (ages 30, 27, 18, 14, 12 and 6). She has a hardware business which she began 8 years ago. She works from 8am to 6pm daily making a monthly profit of about US$171.

In the past, Kibibi has taken out one previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase her business. She hopes for a new loan to increase her capital. Kibibi will share this loan with her subgroup members selling timber wood, bricks, hardware and charcoal.

In the picture, Kibibi is in the middle of the back row.

loans.use: To buy more building materials for her business

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.es:
Eduardo is 35 years old and lives with his wife and son. He is in the transportation business, driving a motorcycle taxi. His wife sells ‘anticuchos’ (a dish consisting of grilled, skewered meat) and, in this way, the family receives two different incomes. Even if Eduardo works locally and there is quite a lot of competition from many motorcycle taxi associations, the demand for this service is high, so he has enough clients.

With the present loan, Eduardo will buy a motorcycle and will also pay off a debt. He has an excellent credit report and, for as long as he has worked with Agrocapital, he has demonstrated to be a responsible and punctual person.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Eduardo es un señor de 35 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y un hijo. Eduardo se dedica a la actividad del transporte, ya que trabaja como mototaxista. Su esposa por otra parte se dedica a la venta de anticuchos y de esta manera la familia diversifica sus ingresos. El servicio que presta Eduardo es a nivel local y si bien existe bastante competencia, por la cantidad de asociaciones de mototaxistas, también hay bastante demanda por este servicio, y por esta razón no le faltan clientes.

Con la presente solicitud comprará una motocicleta y también cancelará un saldo deudor que tiene a la fecha. Eduardo tiene excelentes antecedentes crediticios y en el tiempo que trabaja con Agrocapital siempre demostró ser una persona responsable y puntual.

loans.use: Purchase of motorcycle and debt payment.

loans.name: Victor Hugo

texts.es:
Victor makes different types of furniture from wood, and his business is located in the area of the May 1st highway.

His family is made up of his wife and children. Victor takes care of all the family expenses and his wife helps out with income she receives from the sale of raw milk. The family is very hard-working and continually looks for ways to get ahead.

Currently Victor is in the process of putting up his own carpentry workshop and is building a structure onto his home for this purpose. He would like to take advantage of the broad experience he has and above all, the steady clients who appreciate his work.

The competition in this sector is high, but Victor´s success is based on the quality of the finished work of his furniture. With the current loan request, Victor will buy different types of wood as well as iron and zinc with which to make a small shed where he can store his materials. Prices are stable and vary depending on the type of furniture, quality of wood, manual work, etc.

Victor currently has debts with small institutions which he pays off punctually, the same as he does with our institution.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Victor es un señor que se dedica a la fabricación de diferentes muebles de madera su negocio se encuentra ubicado en el sector de camino a 1ro de Mayo.

Su familia esta compuesta por su esposa y por los hijos, Victor se encarga de todos los gastos de la familia y la esposa le colabora con los ingresos que percibe por la venta de leche cruda. Esta familia es muy trabajadora y constantemente buscan el superarse.

Victor actualmente esta independizandose para poder tener su propia carpintería y está construyendo en su domicilio una estructura para poder armarla, él quiere aprovechar la gran experiencia que tiene y sobre todo la clientela fija que aprecia su trabajo.

La competencia en este sector es elevada, pero el éxito de Victor se basa en la calidad de acabado de sus muebles. Con la presente solicitud Victor comprará madera de diferentes tipos, también comprará fierro y calamina para poder hacer un pequeño galpon donde armará y depositará su materia prima. Los precios son estables y varian dependiendo del tipo de mueble, la calidad de la madera, trabajo manual, etc. Actualmente Victor tiene deudas en pequeñas instituciones las cuales cancela de manera puntual al igual que con nuestra Institución.

loans.use: Working capital and construction.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Valentina

texts.es:
Valentina has a family of five children, her husband works abroad and sends money every month. Her children are of different ages and she looks after them by giving them security and taking care of their needs as well as feeding the family.

Her business is located on Tarata y Esteban Arce Street, where she has a fixed stall under her husband´s name. With many years´ experience, she sell women´s clothing from Korea, which is in high demand.

There is a lot of competition but the difference is in the quality of service that the seller offers her clients. As far as the products are concerned, whether they are imported or local, she has been successful with her stall selling women´s clothing.

The merchandise that she will buy is women´s clothing from Korea. The prices vary and are a bit higher than locally produced but the clothing is of good material and fits the demand of the market.

Valentina is approved for credit with our institution since this is her fourth time and she has always paid her debts with responsibility and punctuality.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Valentina tiene una familia compuesta por cinco hijos, el esposo trabaja en el extranjero y envía dinero mensualmente, los hijos tienen diferentes edades y la madre esta al cuidado de ellos brindandoles seguridad y cubriendo todas sus necesidades y también el sustento familiar.

El negocio esta ubicado en la calle Tarata y Esteban Arce tiene un puesto fijo que esta a nombre del esposo. Con muchos años de experiencia, vende prendas de mujer exlusivamente industria coreana los cuales tienen mucha demanda.

Existe mucha competencia pero la diferencia en la ropa de mujer esta en la calidad de trato que la vendedora ofrece a sus clientes y en cuanto a los productos si son importados o nacionales tiene bastante éxito con su caseta de ropa de mujer.

La mercaderia que va adquirir es ropa exclusivamente para dama de industria coreana los precios son variables y un poco mas elevados que la nacional es de muy buena tela y de acuerdo a la exigencia de la mujer actual.

Valentina esta fidelizada con nuestra institucion ya que es su cuarta secuencia y siempre ha cancelado con mucha responsabilidad y puntualidad.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal merchandise.

loans.name: Maria Antonieta De

texts.es:
Maria Antonieta lives with her children, who are now adults and independent. As far as her expenses go, her husband who lives in the U.S. sends money to maintain their home, but to cover expenses Maria works on her own.

Maria sells clothing and cosmetics for women by catalog. Her business is targeted exclusively to this type since everything she sells can be found in catalogs. The prices vary according to the quality of the product line.

The competition in this type of door-to-door business is quite high, but Maria has several regular customers who appreciate her punctuality in delivering the products and above all, her perseverance. The way she treats her customers is also very important .

With this current request, Maria will buy women´s clothing and cosmetics from the different product lines she works with; prices vary depending on the line.

Maria is approved with our institution as this is her third loan and during the time she has worked with Agrocapital she has shown herself to be very responsible.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Maria Antonieta vive con sus hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad e independientes en cuanto a sus gastos, su esposo se encuentra en EEUU de donde les manda dinero para la mantención del hogar, pero para poder cubrir los gastos Maria trabaja de manera independiente.

Maria se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos por catalogo para mujeres, su negocio está dirigido exclusivamente a este´género ya que todo lo que oferta se encuentra en catálogos de diferentes líneas. Los precios de los artículos que vende varian dependiendo de la calidad de la línea.

La competencia en este tipo de negocios ambulantes es muy elevada, pero Maria cuenta con bastante clientela fija que la aprecia por su puntualidad en la entrega de productos y sobre todo por su perseverancia. Es muy importante también el trato que le da a sus clientes.

Con la presente solicitud Maria comprará ropa de mujer y cosméticos de diferentes líneas con las que trabaja, los precios son variables dependiendo la línea. Maria está totalmente fidelizada con nuestra institución ya que esta es la tercera secuencia y en el tiempo de trabajo con Agrocapital demostró ser una persona muy responsable.

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Elizabeth's Kipunguni Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, age 32, is married and owns a video library where she works from 8am to 7pm daily. She started this business in 2007 and now makes a monthly profit of about $180 from her rentals.

Elizabeth now hopes for a loan to increase her video stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup. They belong to the loan group called Kipunguni, whose members keep each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Elizabeth is 1st on the right ,standing

loans.use: To purchase more video stock for her library

loans.name: Ivone Ingrid

texts.es:
Ivone lives with her husband and children. Her husband is a security guard at the CENDI school. The couple has a family business which they take care of with the support of her mother in-law, who helps out at their stand.
They have several businesses. During the day Ivone and her brother run an internet cafe which is located in Villa San Andres. On the weekends, together with her mother in-law, they sell chicharrón (a dish make of pork) and chicha (a drink from fermented corn).
The competition in both businesses is very high, but what differentiates this family from others is that they mobilize to sell their chicharrón and chicha in different places, and they also treat their customers in a very preferential manner.
The current loan request is to increase their working capital, as they need money to buy computer equipment. The prices for the equipment vary depending on the quality and above all the memory.
Ivone is approved with this institution as she has had several loans and has always demonstrated responsibility and punctuality. 
Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Ivone vive junto con su esposo e hijos, su esposo es guardia de seguridad del colegio CENDI. La pareja tiene un negocio familiar que lo llevan adelante con la ayuda de la suegra que les colabora con la atención del local.
Tienen varios negocios Ivone junto a su hermano atienden un café internet durante el día que se encuentra ubicado en Villa San Andres y los fines de semana atienden junto a la suegra el negocio de venta de chicharrón y chicha.
La competencia en ambos rubros es muy elevada, lo que diferencia a la familia del resto es que ellos se movilizan para vender su mercadería de chicharrón y chicha y así dstribuyen en varios lugares, además que tratan a sus clientes de manera preferencial.
La presente solicitud es para el incremento de capital de operaciones, ya que le faltó dinero para la compra de un equipo de computación, en cuanto a los precios de los equipos de computación varian dependiendo la calidad y la capacidad que tienen estos sobre todo de memoria.
Ivone esta muy fidelizada con la institución ya que lleva varias frecuencias en la misma y siempre demostro responsabilidad y puntualidad.

loans.use: Increase working capital.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Limber Alejandro

texts.es:
Limber is an employee at a company. He is single and lives with his parents. He works hard to provide services as an electrician. Currently, Limber is also a student. He seeks a loan to increase the savings that will be used to buy a computer. Limber needs this computer, for it will facilitate his job and help him in school projects. He has a very good credit history during his time with Agrocapital; he demonstrated that he is very responsible and punctual in his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Limber es un joven que trabaja como dependiente de una empresa. Es una persona soltera que vive con sus padres y se dedica a prestar servicios de electricista en la empresa donde trabaja. Actualmente Limber continúa estudiando y la presente solicitud es para incrementar capital que necesita para comprar una computadora. Limber requiere esta computadora ya que la misma le facilitará la elaboración de trabajos y proyectos en sus estudios. Tiene muy buenos antecedentes crediticios, durante el tiempo de relación financiera con Agrocapital demostró ser una persona responsable y puntual en sus pagos.

loans.use: buy a computer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Fatuma's Msimamo E Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 38, is married with 2 children (ages 14 and 8). She has a business of selling eggs, which she started 3 years ago. She works at her business from 9am to 6pm daily and makes about $210 in profit a month.

In the past, Fatuma took out 2 loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy scrap metal parts to sell and was able to repay them back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to buy eggs to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members have businesses dealing in food, eggs, and drink sales.

In the picture, Fatuma is in the middle at the back row.

loans.use: To buy eggs to sell

loans.name: Nedžada

texts.en: Nedžada, 28 years old, is from Orahovica, a suburb of the town of Zenica. She breeds cows and with her  husband sells seasonal  agricultural products. They can earn about 400 KM  monthly, but that money is not enough for them and their 2 children, ages 5 and 8. This will be her second loan in the amount of $775 (1000 KM), which she will use to buy animal nutrients in order to  increase the household income.

loans.use: To purchase animal nutrients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more products for her store.

loans.name: Behija

texts.en: Behija, born in 1959, is from  Orahovica,  a suburb of  Zenica. Her  husband receives a monthly pension of 400 KM.  They own cows, and she requests a loan of $775 (1000 KM ) to buy animal nutrients in order to increase her monthly family income.

loans.use: To buy animal nutrients.

loans.name: Adisa

texts.en: Adisa, 27 years old and married with 2 daughters. lives in Orahovica, a suburb of the town of Zenica. With her husband she sells milk and milk products, which earns them a monthly income of 400 KM.  Adisa requests  this loan in the amount of $775 (1000 KM)  in order to purchase animal nutrients so they can earn more money  selling  their  products.

loans.use: To buy animal nutrients.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina Y. is a polite and hard-working entrepreneur in Berdyansk, Ukraine. Known for her honesty and dedication, she works long hours running her own small clothing store, which sells mainly athletic wear and socks.

Irina's lucky because her store is located in an excellent location, so she has an excellent sale rate. That's why she's confident she will be able to repay a loan of $500 U.S. dollars in full. Irina is single and lives with her parents, but the high inflation rate in the Ukraine is making it difficult for her family to maintain their basic standard of living. With the loan, Irina hopes to purchase more inventory to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for a small retail store

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia works both independently and dependently; in the morning she works in her convenient store located in Villa Pagador where she can be found until four in the afternoon, after that from 5:00 pm to 11:00 at night she works as a cashier at a restaurant called "El palacio del Silpancho."

Virginia is single and the income that she receives helps her with the expenses of her home since she still lives with her parents. In both businesses she has over five years experience.

Her ability and security in both positions is elevated by her time spent in the business; in the first business she deals with a fixed clientel, and in the case of the restaurant, it's very stable since she is rather well known and visited by many of the residents of Cochambamba and also foreigners.

The current loan request is to complete her savings for capital needed in order to buy a car, which will cost $3000. This acquisition will enable her to move around better.

Virginia has very good prior credit; her performance with the institution is responsible and her payments are punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

Virginia trabaja de manera independiente y dependiente, el las mañanas se encarga de su bodega que se encuentra ubicada en Villa Pagador hasta las cuatro de la tarde, después a partir de las 5:00 de la tarde hasta las 11:00 de la noche trabaja como cajera en un restaurant llamado "El palacio del Sillpancho".

Virginia es soltera y los ingresos que percibe sirven para ayudar en los gastos de su casa ya que aún vive con sus papás. En ambos negocios tiene una experiencia de más de 5 años.

La competencia en ambos rubros es elevada pero por la antiguedad que tiene en el primer negocio ya cuenta con clientela fija y en el caso del restaurante es un negocio muy estable ya que el mismo es bastante conocido y visitado por habitantes de Cochambamba y extranjeros.

La presente solicitud es para completar capital para poder comprar un vehículo que costará en total $us, 3,000.-. Esta adquisición le permitirá movilizarse de mejor manera.

Virginia cuenta con antecedentes crediticios muy buenos, su comportamiento con la Institución es responsable y puntual en sus pagos.

loans.use: Complete capital to purchase a car.

loans.name: Griselda

texts.es:
“My husband, my two children and I used to live with my parents, we saved money to buy a piece of land and build two rooms. Upon finishing the building went to live there. We have been living in those rooms for 1 year and now we would like to build one more room as we need space and room for our children.” I am asking for a $1000 to build a room on my home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

“Mi esposo y mis dos hijos vivíamos con mis papas, estuvimos ahorrando dinero para comprar un terreno y construir dos cuartos, cuando terminamos la construcción nos pudimos ir a vivir ahí; ya tenemos 1 año habitando esos cuartos pero ahora nos gustaría hacer un cuarto más ya que necesitamos espacio y comodidad para nuestros hijos”. Solicito $ 1000.00 dlls para construir un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Build a room on our home

loans.name: Juan Diego

texts.es:
“I have some unfinished construction on the front of my home which I had to abandon due to health problems and incurred expenses. Now, thank God, I am perfectly healthy and I need to finish expanding my home.” I am asking for $1200 to finish the construction of a room on my home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

“Tengo una construcción sin terminar enfrente de mi vivienda la cual tuve que detener debido a que tuve problemas de salud y realice algunos gastos, ahora gracias a dios ya estoy perfectamente bien y necesito terminar la ampliación de mi vivienda” Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para terminar la ampliación de un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Finish construction on home expansion

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
My husband and I have a shop attached to our house. We work in it and it is going well, but now we think we should invest in more merchandise to increase sales since the warmer season is coming. We request $300 to invest in our business.

This story has been translated from Spanish to English by Nikita Ramchandani, KIVA Volunteer.

“Mi esposo y yo tenemos una tienda de abarrotes en nuestra casa, la atendemos los y nos va bien con las ventas, pero ahora pensamos que debemos invertir en la compra de mercancía y aumentar nuestra ventas ya que esta por entrar la temporada de calor” Solicito $ 300.00 dlls para invertir en nuestro negocio.

loans.use: To invest in my business.

loans.name: Kate May Carolina

texts.es:
The small business owner, Kate May Caroline N. M. is 59 years old and is originally from Bluefields. She is married, ethnically creole and is the mother of 3 children. One studies in secondary school and is the oldest of the three. Mrs. N. has been dedicated to the business of selling clothes and footwear in the shopping center in the city. As she is ethnically creole, she has many creole clients that prefer to buy from her, even though there are many similar businesses in the shopping center. With his small business, N. has been able to maintain an economical lifestyle. However, just like others in her business, she needs help to buy better inventory of fashionable clothes. She wants to buy 2 dozen women's blouses that cost $48 per dozen, 2 dozen children suits that cost $60 per dozen, 1 dozen pants that cost $102 per dozen, 8 pairs of sandals that cost $4 each, 1 dozen of one type of pants that cost $25 per dozen and 1 dozen of another type of pants that cost $95 per dozen.

This story has been translated from Spanish to English by Nikita Ramchandani, KIVA Volunteer.

La microempresaria Kate May Carolina N. M. tiene 59 años de edad, es originaria de Bluefields, es casada, de la etnia creole, madre de 3 hijos, 1 estudia en secundaria y dos mayores de edad. La señora N. se dedica desde hace 15 años aproximadamente a la venta de ropas y calzados en el centro comercial de esta ciudad. Por ser de la etnia creole tiene muchos clientes de esa etnia que la prefieren a pesar que en este centro comercial hay otros negocios similares. Con este negocio la microempresaria N. a podido mantenerse economicamente pero al igual que otras microempresarias necesita de un financiamiento para poder comprar mayor inventario de ropas a la moda, por lo que quiere comprar: 2 docenas de blusas de mujer a US$ 84 dolares cada docena, 2 docenas de trajes de niños a US$ 60 dolares cada docena, 1 docena de pantalones Studio a US$ 102 dolares cada docena, 8 pares de sandalias a US$ 4 dolares cada par, 1 docena de pantalones Justo a US$ 25 dolares cada docena y 1 docena de pantalones Bring a US$ 95 dolares cada docena.

loans.use:
To buy 2 dozen blouses, 2 dozen children suits, 1 dozen paints, eight dozen sandals, 1 dozen of one type of pants and 1 dozen of another type of pants.
.

payments.comment:
La cuota es de US 44.38  
Su cuota le tocaba el dia 05-Abril-2,008.
La cuota real es de US$ 44.38
La cuota real es de US$ 44.38
La cuota real de pago es de $ 44.38 dólares.

loans.name: Manuel Angel

texts.es:
Over time the walls in my house have deteriorated . I would like to repair them before they start to fall in pieces, and most of all for the security of my family. I request $1000 in order to make these reparations to my house.

This story has been translated from Spanish to English by NIkita Ramchandani, KIVA Volunteer,

“Con el tiempo las paredes de mi casa se has ido deteriorando me gustaría repararlas antes de que se empiecen a caer en pedazos, más que nada por la seguridad de mi familia” Solicito $ 1000.00 dlls para reparar las paredes de mi vivienda

loans.use: To repair the walls of my home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in more plastic bottles of water and hire more workers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in school supplies and other merchandise

loans.name: Epifania Francisca's Group

texts.en:
Francisca and Cirila have been members of the community bank Manantial for close to ten years. In that time, they have learned to save, be punctual, and to be responsible.

Francisca is 50 years old. She is married and has six children. Francisca is from the community of Rancha, which is a little town outsiD. the city of Ayacucho. Francisca travels to different markets in the region where she sells fruits and homemaD. breads. From the markets, she buys meat and cheeses that she sells in the city of Ayacucho and sometimes in the city of Lima. Recently, Francisca started a new business raising chickens and pigs.

Cirila is 50 years old. She is married and has eight children, three of whom live with her. Cirila buys chesses from various markets around the region of Ayacucho. She then sells them to restaurant and middle men who take them to the jungle region.

Francisca and Cirila need loans of 1000 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying things such as pigs, chicks, potatoes, and cheese.

One of the most important things about the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Francisca and Cirila plan to use their savings to pay for their children’s education. Their dreams are that their businesses will continue to grow and their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Francisca and Cirila need loans of 1000 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying things such as pigs, chicks, potatoes, and cheese.

loans.name: Gricelda's Group

texts.en:
Noemí, Isabel, and Gricelda are members of the community bank Manantial. Noemi joined just one year ago, while Isabel and Griselda have been members for five years. In the community bank they have learned how to be responsible, how to be punctual, how to treat their children, and how to manage their business.

Noemi is 22 years old. She lives with her partner and their four-year-old daughter. Noemi and her husband have a painting business. In addition, Noemi owns a motorcycle taxi, of which she uses to transport people.

Gricelda is 48 years old. She is married and has two children. Gricelda has a small store located in her home. From there she sells food staples such as rice, sugar, and flower. In addition she sells fruits, vegetables, and meat.

Isabel is 69 years old. She is married and has four children, of whom only one still lives with her. Isabel sells vegetables and grains from a kiosk located on a central corner near her house in Ayacucho.

Noemi, Isabel, and Gricelda need loans of 1500, 1000, and 750 soles (3 soles = $1), respectively, which they will use to buy rice, sugar, oil, soft drinks, milk, pasta, potatoes, and to register the motorcycle taxi.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Noemi, Isabel, and Gricelda plan to use their savings to make improvements to their homes and to pay for their daughter to graduate from university.

loans.use: Noemi, Isabel, and Gricelda need loans of 1500, 1000, and 750 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy rice, sugar, oil, soft drinks, milk, pasta, potatoes, and to make register the motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Domptila

texts.fr:
Thirty-four years old and married, Domptila has been a member of her group for the last four and a half years. She specializes in selling lemon juice, forest products (palm oil) and processed fish products (dried fish), etc. She has gained solid experience in these areas. This loan will allow her to strengthen her production. She plans to reimburse it with a one-time repayment in six months.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Agée de 34 ans, mariée, Domptila est membre de son groupement depuis quatre ans et demi. Elle s'est spécialisée dans le commerce de jus de citron, de produits forestiers (huile de palme) et de produits halieutiques transformés (poissons séchés), etc.. Elle a acquis une bonne expérience dans ce domaine. Ce prêt va lui permettre de renforcer ses marchandises. Elle s'engage à le rembourser au bout de 6 mois en une seule fois.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies

loans.name: Zonia Blanca

texts.en:
Zonia has been a member of the community bank “Buena Suerte” for 12 years. She was one of the founding members. Through her work with the community bank Zonia has leaned to save and to live her life according to her personal values.

Zonia is 60 years old. She is a widow and has seven children, two of whom live with her. Zonia is a tailor; she makes dress clothes to order for established clients. Her workshop is located in her house. Zonia also knits beautiful sweaters and baby clothes which she sells to friends and family members.

In addition, Zonia sells cosmetics from a catalogue. She brings these products from Lima and sells them to friends and family.

Zonia needs a loan of 3000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying things such as fabrics, lotions, and shampoo.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Zonia plans to use her savings to pay for her daughter and niece’s education. Her dreams are to be successful, travel to another country, and to ensure that her daughter will have a better life.

loans.use: Zonia needs a loan of 3000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying things such as fabrics, lotions, and shampoo.

loans.name: Gloria Vilma

texts.en:
Gloria has been an associate of the community bank Manantial for 14 years. Through the bank, she has learned to save and to be responsible.

Gloria is 39 years old. She is married and has two children who are twenty and seventeen years old. Gloria is from the community of Chacco, in the region of Ayacucho. Gloria and her husband work in the agricultural sector. They have fields where they grow cilantro, carrots, and cauliflower. They sell their products at the markets in the city of Ayacucho. Gloria also raises cattle.

Gloria needs a loan of 2000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying seeds, fertilizers, and renting additional fields.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account that each associate has. Gloria plans to use her savings to build a home. Her dream is that her children will be professionals, be able to open a fertilizer store, and to increase the number of cattle she raises.

loans.use: Gloria needs a loan of 2000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying seeds, fertilizers, and renting additional fields.

loans.name: Diarra Seydou

texts.fr:
Born in 1946, Diarra has been a member Hathioume’s BV located in the Ziguinchor region (southern Senegal) for the last six years. She is mother to a family who she supports with earnings from her small business. She sells hand-crafted brooms made from tree twigs. She is seeking a seventh loan to strengthen her business. Diarra offers to pay back this loan with a one-time reimbursement in six months.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1946, Diarra est membre du BV de Hathioume situé dans la région de Ziguinchor (Sud du Sénégal) depuis six ans. Elle est mère de famille qu'elle entretien avec les revenus tirés de son petit commerce. Elle vend des balaies de fabrication artisanale à partir de tiges d'arbre. Elle sollicite un 7ème prêt pour renforcer son activité. Diarra propose de rembourser ce prêt au bout de 6 mois en une seule fois.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies

loans.name: Carmen Rosario

texts.es:
Carmen has belonged to the Communal Bank “Amor Divino” for 8 years. In her Communal Bank she learned to be responsible, how to educate her children, and how to plan her family.

Carmen is married, 55 years old, and has 6 children, 4 of whom live with her. Carmen is originally from Compañía. Carmen, together with her brothers, makes bricks, and with the help of laborers create the bricks, then dry them in the sun, later bake them in the oven. She sells the bricks right where they are made.

During the rainy season Carmen travels to the markets where she sells vegetables, fruit, and from the markets she brings beans, wheat, barley, cheese – products she sells in the Nery Garcia market.

Carmen needs a loan of 2000 soles which she will invest in the purchase of wood and her worker’s wages.

Her savings will be used to educate her children and for the construction of a second floor of her home.

Carmen dreams that her children will be professionals, her business will grow, and she will buy another piece of land to keep making bricks.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Carmen pertenece al Banco Comunal “Amor Divino” hace 8 años. En su Banco Comunal aprendió a ser responsable, como educar a los hijos y como planificar su familia.

Carmen es casada, tiene 55 años y 6 hijos de los cuales solo 4 viven con ella, Carmen es natural de la comunidad de Compañía. Carmen junto a sus hermanos hacen ladrillos, y con la ayuda de peones labran el ladrillo, luego se hace secar al sol y posteriormente se quema en el horno, sus ventas lo realiza en el mismo lugar y también puesto en obra.

Además Carmen en las épocas de lluvias, viaja a las ferias donde vende verduras, frutas y de las ferias trae haba, trigo, cebada, queso, productos que vende en el mercado Nery García.

Carmen necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña y para el pago de los peones.

Sus ahorros lo utilizará en los gastos de educación de sus hijos y para la construcción de la segunda planta de su casa.

Los sueños de Carmen con que sus hijos sean profesionales, su negocio sea mas grande y comprar otro terreno para seguir haciendo ladrillos.

loans.use: Carmen needs a loan of 2000 soles which she will invest in the purchase of wood and her worker’s wages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in merchandise for his store and also his food making production for the weekends

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica C. C. has an electronics repair shop in the city of Morales, San Martin. She runs the shop with the help of her husband and other family members. They started the shop 10 years ago and have slowly become an established business in the community with many loyal customers.

Monica is 28 years old and has 2 children. She loves having a family business where she can take care of her children and work at the same time. Monica is friendly, charismatic, and loves building relationships. She is very well known in the community. She has an optimistic view on life and looks forward to sending her children to University.

A member of Manuela Ramos and the community bank Las Moralinas, Monica is requesting a loan of $250 to repay over 4 months. She plans to use the loan to buy copper wire and soldering equipment.

loans.use: To buy copper wire and soldering equipment for her electronics repair shop

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
Maria Elena B. A. runs a general store in the city of Morales, San Martin. Maria offers her community essential products, such as ingredients for popular local dishes, candy, drinks, and hygiene products. She started the store one year ago and has experienced a steady increase of sales.

Maria is 50 years old, married, and has 5 children. An ex-school teacher, Maria is content providing this valuable service to her community. Family is very important to Maria. She wants to make sure she continues to have a second income so her children can have more opportunities in life than she has had.

A member of Manuela Ramos and the community bank Las Moralinas, Maria is requesting a loan of $300 to repay over 6 months. She plans to use the loan to restock her store with beer, oil, and rice.

loans.use: To restock her store with beer, oil, and rice.

loans.name: Lucinda Esther

texts.en:
Lucinda Esther R. S. has a business selling clothing door to door in the region of San Martin. Lucinda lives in the city of Morales, where she and her husband started the business 3 years ago. They’ve experienced success because they travel to remote towns in the region and sell clothes to people that usually wouldn’t have the opportunity to buy these clothes.

Lucinda is 33 years old, happily married and has 4 children (pictured here). Her family is very close and supportive. She is proud of her accomplishments and business. Education is very important in her family and she is motivated to succeed so she can send all of her children to University.

A member of Manuela R. and the community bank Las Moralinas, Lucinda is requesting a loan of $700 to repay over 6 months. She plans to use the loan to increase her inventory of clothes to sell.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Raquel Lourdes' Group

texts.es:
Guadalupe, Raquel and Gloria belong to the Communal Bank “Musuq Rumi,” which means “New Stone” in Quechua, for 1 year, 1 year, and 8 months respectively.

In their Communal Bank they learned to be punctual, responsible, learned about nutrition and above all how to save money.

Guadalupe is married, 45 years old, and has 6 children. Guadalupe sells “salchipapas” (a dish maD. with potatoes and fried chicken) from her home’s door every evening, an activity she has been doing for 1 year. In addition, Guadalupe works during the day in construction. Guadalupe is planning to travel to area markets to buy cheese, grains and then sell them in Ayacucho city.

Raquel is married, 37 years old, with 6 children. Raquel travels to different markets in the region where she sells groceries and fruit; from the markets she bring grains, small animals, and cheese as products to sell in the Ayacucho markets.

Gloria is married, 54 years old, and has 7 children. Gloria has a store in her home where she sells groceries and vegetables.

Guadalupe, Raquel and Gloria need loans of 400 soles, 200 soles, and 400 soles respectively, and the money will be invested in the purchase of barley, cheese, wheat, beans, sugar and rice.

They will use their savings to educate their children and increase their earnings.

Guadalupe, Raquel and Gloria dream of having a store in their homes, that their children will be professionals, and having more capital for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Guadalupe, Raquel y Gloria pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Musuq Rumi”, que significa “Nueva Piedra” en quechua, hace 1 año, 1 año y 8 meses respectivamente.

En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables, acerca D. nutrición y sobre todo a ahorrar.

Guadalupe es casada, tiene 45 años y 6 hijos, Guadalupe venD. salchipapas (comida hecha con papas y pollo frito) en la puerta D. su casa todas las noches, actividad que realiza hace 1 año. Además Guadalupe durante el día trabaja en actividades D. construcción. Guadalupe tiene pensado viajar a las ferias para comprar queso, cereales y luego comercializarlo en la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Por otro lado, Raquel es casada, tiene 37 años y 6 hijos, Raquel viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región donD. venD. abarrotes, frutas y D. las ferias trae cereales, animales menores y queso, productos que venD. en los mercados D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Mientras que Gloria es casada, tiene 54 años y 7 hijos, Gloria tiene una tienda donD. venD. abarrotes, verduras, ubicado en su casa.

Guadalupe, Raquel y Gloria necesitan préstamos D. 400 soles, 200 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cebada, queso, trigo, habas, azúcar y arroz.

Sus ahorros lo utilizaran en la educación D. sus hijos y para incrementar el capital D. sus negocios.

Los sueños D. Guadalupe, Raquel y Gloria son tener una tienda en su casa, que sus hijos sean profesionales y tener más capital para sus negocios.

loans.use: Guadalupe, Raquel and Gloria need loans of 400 soles, 200 soles, and 400 soles respectively, and the money will be invested in the purchase of barley, cheese, wheat, beans, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Maria Pilar's Group

texts.es:
Maria, Maritza and Edilbert have been members of a communal bank, "Musuq Rumi" which means "New Stone" in Quechua (a tribal name and language of some native Latin Americans) for 3, 2, and 3 years, respectively.

Here, they learned to save, be punctual, invest their money and take care of their children.

Maria is a citizen, 24 years old, and has 2 children. Maria knits beautiful sweaters. She makes her pieces with her hands and with a weaver that she bought 1 year ago. She sells her pieces to stores.

Next to Maria is Maritza, who is 28 and married with 2 children. Maritza has a store where she sells grocery items and vegetables. The store is located in her mother's home. In addition, Maritza sells clothes for the military.

Meanwhile, Edilberta is married, 52, and has 4 children. She knits sweaters and satchels by hand. Her pieces are sold to families, neighbors and at stores.

Maria, Martiza, and Edilberta need a loan of 200 soles, 400 soles, and 400 soles, respectively. The loans will be used to invest in wool, linen, caps, polos.

Their savings will be used for their children's education. Their dreams are that their businesses will grow, their children will become professionals, they will be able to buy some land and have their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Maria, Maritza y Edilberta pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Musuq Rumi” que significa “Nueva Piedra” en quechua, hace 3, 2, 3 años respectivamente.

En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ahorrar, ser puntuales, como invertir el dinero y como tratar a los hijos.

Maria es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Maria teje bellas chompas, sus trabajos lo hace a mano y también con una maquina de tejer que fue adquirida hace 1 año, sus productos lo vende a tiendas.

Por otro lado Maritza es casada, tiene 28 años y 2 hijos, Maritza tiene una tienda donde vende abarrotes, verduras, ubicada en casa de su mama. Además Maritza vende ropa para militares a crédito.

Mientras que Edilberta es casada, tiene 52 años y 4 hijos, Edilberta teje chompas y carteras a mano, sus productos los vende a familiares, vecinos y también a tiendas.

Maria, Maritza y Edilberta necesitan un préstamo de 200 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana, hilos, gorras, polos.

Sus ahorros lo utilizarán en los gastos de educación de sus hijos. Los sueños de Maria, Maritza y Edilberta son que sus negocios sean mas grandes, que sus hijos sean profesionales, comprar un terreno y tener casa propia.

loans.use: Maria, Maritza and Edilberta need loans of 200 soles, 400 soles, and 400 soles, respectively, to buy more linen, wool, caps, and polos.

loans.name: Olga Marisol's Group

texts.en:
Olga, Fresquita and Cirila have belonged to the New Rock Community Bank (Banco Comunal Musuq Rumi) for 4 months, 4 months and 1 year respectively. In their community bank, their learned values such as how to manage money and be good helpers.

Olga is 34 years old, married and has 3 daughters. Olga sells “emoliente” (a drink made with herbs and flax seed which has healing properties) in the street in the mornings. Olga also has a café in an institute where she sells sweets and meals. Sometimes Olga cleans businesses.

Fresquita lives with her partner, is 21 years old and has a one year old son. Fresquita has been selling vegetables and spices in the Mariscal Caceres market during the last 2 years. She also studies tailoring.

Cirila lives with her partner, is 26 years old and has a 9 year old daughter. Cirila sells groceries, vegetables and fruit out of her home.

Olga, Fresquita and Cirila need loans for 400, 400 and 600 soles respectively. This money will be used to purchase soft drinks, cookies, chocolates, cumin, garlic, chilies, vinegar, rice, pasta and sugar.

Their savings will be used for the education of their children, to increase the capital for their businesses and build their homes. Their dreams are that their children become professionals in the workplace, have a large business, their own home, finish their studies and work.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Olga, Fresquita y Cirila pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Musuq Rumi” que significa “Nueva Piedra” en quechua, hace 4 meses, 4 meses, 1 año respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron los valores, como manejar el dinero y ser colaboradoras en todo.

Olga es casada, tiene 34 años y 3 hijas, Olga vende emoliente, (bebida caliente elaborada con hierbas y semillas de lino, contiene propiedades curativas), de manera ambulante, actividad que realiza por las mañanas. Además Olga tiene un cafetín en un instituto, donde vende golosinas y comida. Algunas veces Olga hace limpieza en instituciones.

Por otro lado Fresquita es conviviente, tiene 21 años y 1 hijo de 1 año, Fresquita vende verduras y especerías en el mercado Mariscal Cáceres, actividad que realiza hace 2 años. Además Fresquita estudia corte y confección.

Mientras Cirila es conviviente, tiene 26 años y 1 hija de 9 años, Cirila tiene una tienda de venta de abarrotes, verduras, frutas ubicada en su casa.

Olga, Fresquita y Cirila necesitan un préstamo de 400 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosas, galletas, chocolates, comino, ajo, ají, vinagre, arroz, fideo y azúcar.

Sus ahorros lo utilizarán en la educación de sus hijos, para incrementar el capital de sus negocios y construir su casa. Los sueños de Olga, Fresquita y Cirila son que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales, tener una tienda grande, casa propia, terminar sus estudios y trabajar.

loans.use: Olga, Fresquita and Cirila need loans for 400, 400 and 600 soles respectively.  This money will be used to purchase soft drinks, cookies, chocolates, cumin, garlic, chilies, vinegar, rice, pasta and sugar.

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.en:
Marina and Zenaida have been members of the Divine Love Community Bank (Banco Comunal Amor Divino) for 12 years and 1 year respectively. In their community bank, they learned responsibility, saving, managing a business and self-esteem. Marina mentioned that with her savings she bought land and built her house.

Marina is 51 years old, divorced and has a son. Marina has a small general store in the province of San Miguel which is located 3 hours from the city of Ayacucho, where she lives. Her products are brought from Ayacucho. Marina also sells fish, chicken and trout by special order.

Zenaida lives with her partner, is 28 years old and has one daughter. Zenaida has a photocopy and printing store where she also sells photocopiers. It is located on a central street in Ayacucho. Zenaida also will open a café in a local institute.

Marina and Zenaida need loans for 600 soles and 1000 soles. This money will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, soap and to start a new business as a café.

Their savings will be used to build their house, capital for their businesses and their children’s studies. Marina and Zenaida’s dreams are that their children will become professionals in the workforce, earn more capital, have their own homes and give all the best to her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Marina y Zenaida pertenecen al Banco Comunal Amor Divino hace 12, 1 año respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser responsables, a ahorrar, como administrar su negocio y tener autoestima. Marina menciona que con sus ahorros que reunió en su Banco Comunal compró su terreno y construyó su casa.

Marina es divorciada, tiene 51 años y 1 hijo, Marina tiene una tienda de abarrotes en la provincia de San Miguel ubicada a 3 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho, ciudad donde vive, sus productos son llevados de Ayacucho. Además Marina vende pescado, pollo, trucha por pedido.

Mientras que Zenaida es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 1 hija, Zenaida tiene una tienda de fotocopias, impresiones y también venta de fotocopiadoras, ubicada en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además Zenaida iniciará un cafetín en un instituto local.

Marina y Zenaida necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, jabón y para implementar el nuevo negocio de cafetín.

Sus ahorros lo utilizarán en la construcción de su casa, para incrementar el capital de sus negocios y los estudios de sus hijos. Los sueños de Marina y Zenaida son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener mas capital, casa propia y darle todo lo mejor a su hija.

loans.use: Marina and Zenaida need loans for 600 soles and 1000 soles.  This money will be used to buy rice, sugar, oil, soap and to start a new business as a café.

loans.name: Luz Mary's Group

texts.en:
Luz, Maribel and Elisabeth have belonged to the New Rock Community Bank (Banco Comunal Musuq Rumi) for 8, 4 and 8 months respectively. In their community bank, they learned responsibility, how to invest money, to save and what they can do to overcome hardships.

Luz is 20 years old and single. Luz along with her mother sell food in the Magdalena market. Luz plans to grow her business with the loan she hopes to get. She will sell chicken broth from a tent on Mondays.

On the other hand, Maribel is a 28 year old, single mother of 4 children. Maribel is a street vendor in the Magdalena market selling “emoliente” (a drink made with herbs and flax seed which has healing properties). Maribel also sells regional fruit on occasion.

Elisabeth is 29 years old, has 2 children and lives with her partner. Elisabeth sells food on Fridays and Saturdays at the Ccejelambras and Chontaca fairs. Sometimes Elisabeth sells food at different construction sites. Elisabeth has a planned to open a general store.
